editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE APHORISMES OF HIPPOCRATES PRINCE OF PHYSITIANS.

WITH A hort COMMENT on Them, taken out of thoe larger Notes Of
GALEN.
HEURNIUS
FUCHSIUS, &c.
With an exact Table hewing the ubtance of every APHORISME.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moeley, at the Princes Arms in St. Pauls Church yard. 1655.

div.head: Hippocrates his life out of Soranus.
div.p:
HIppocrates was born in an Iland in the Aegean ea, called Cos or Ccos. and was the on of Heraclides, and Praxithea the daughter of Phenaretes. He reckoned his Pedigree from Hercules and Eculapius, and counted himelf nineteen generations or decents from the one, and twenty from the other. Of his Genealogy Erat • thenes makes mention. and Pherecides and Apollod • rus and Arius Tarenis. He was his Father Heraclides diciple, then to one Her • dicus, and as ome relate, he heard Leontinus the Rhetorician,
<1 page duplicate>
and Democritus the Philoopher of Abdera. He flourihed in Pelops his time: and was born (as Ithomachus relates in his firt book of Hippocrates Sect.) in the firt yeer of the eightieth Olimpiad. But S • ranus a Coan, having earched the Library of Cos, goes further and aith he was born during Abriada his Monarchy the even and twentieth day of the month Agrian, at which time the Coans do to this day offer Sacrifices to Hippocrates. Another Author aith he lived in the times of Eliachim, Malachi, Pereno, and Socrates. He being exceeding skilful in Phyick, and the whole coure of learning, after his parents died forook his native Country (as one Andreas fally imputes to him in a book which he hath written of the Origine of Phyick) for having fired the Cuidians
Library. Others ay he left his Country through a deire he had to ee the effects and ucces of Phyick in everal effects, Climates, and places. But Soranus aith the Lord appeared to him in a dream, and wihed him go to live in Thealia Howoever he was famous all Greece over, and admired for his skill in Phyick o far that he was by Ambaadours ent for to Perdi • cas King of Macedonia when he was thought to lye ick of a Conumption, and came to him, together with one Euryphon, who was elder then he; and by ome ignes and tokens, found that the Kings dieae was a trouble of the mind, for after the death of his Father Alexander, he fell in love with one of his Concubines called Phila: Which Hippocrates dicovered by his pule, in which he felt an alteration
at her coming into the room, and acquainting Phila therewith, cured the King He was alo called to Abdera to recover Democritus from his madnes, and expel the Plague out of the whole City. And the Plague being at a time gotten in amongt the Pahnonians and Illyrians, they ent Ambaadors for him, who having enquired of them what winds ordinarily blew there ent them away unatisfied: and when by prudent Arguments he foreaw the Plague would prevail upon the Atticans dominions, he foretold it, and took great care both of thoe Cities and of his Diciples. And he o truely loved Greece, that the renown of his learning preading it elf as far as Peria, and Artaxerxes ending for him by means of Hytanides Governor of Hellepont, upon
proffer of exceeding great rewards, preferring honety, before lucre of mony, he abolutely denyed him; as by his letter written to him it plainly appears. He freed his own Country, when the Athenians intended to war againt it, and had called the Thealians to aid them, whereupon he had great honors decreed him by the Coans. Yea and by the Thealians, Argives, and Athenians, who entered him into the Eleuinian Sacrifices or myteries, next to Hercules, and admitted him into their franchize, and allowed both him and all his poterity maintenance of Corn out of their common Granaries. He taught all as were tudious of this Art, freely and without envy.

He died amongt the Larieans about that time as Democritus alo died, ome ay at ninety, ome
at eighty five, ome at one hundred and four, ome at a hundred and nine yeers of age. And was buried between Gyrtone and Laria, where his Monument is to this day to be een, in which for a long time there was a warm of Bees, with whoe hony the nures coming to the Monument, would anoint the Ulcers of infants mouths, and cure them. In many of his pictures and Images he is painted with his head covered (ome ay) with a hat, it being a ign of Nobility (for o was lies painted) Some ay his head was covered with his Cloak, which ome affirm was for comelines becaue he was bald, and ome by reaon of the weaknes of his head. But ome will have it done o by him ignificatively to hew that it i • fitting to have the chief • eat of the oul well guarded and
covered. Others ay it is the dres of one who loves travel: ome again ay it was to demontrate the obcurity of his writings. And finally ome that it was to tetifie, that we ought in our health time beware of uch things as may be hurtful to us. Though ome affirm it was becaue his cloak hould not hinder him, hanging about his hands when he was about to give Phyick, and that therefore he wrapped it up and cat it behind his head.

There is great controverie about his writings, o that the • e being everal opinions, it is not eaie to aert any thing certainly concerning them, for many caues which may obcure a mans judgement. As firt his irname Secondly becaue it is not poible to oberve his phrae: Thirdly, becaue that according to his age
he alters it, beides many other reaons; I could (if I pleaed) alleadge. He always contemned mony, was pious, and a lover of the Greeks. Wonderful well-affected to his own Countrymen, o that he freed them all from the Petilence, as I aid before, wherby he was much honored both by them and the Argives and Athenians. He left two ons after his deceae, Thealus and Draca, and a great number of Diciples; but his ons were the mot famous.

div.head: Hippocrates his Oath.
div.p:
I Swear by Apollo the Phyician, Aeculapius, Hygiea, Panacea, and call all the Gods and Goddees to witnes, that I will oberve and keep this underwritten oath to the uttermot of my power & judgement. I wil reverence my Mater who taught me this Art, equally with my Parents, will allow him things neceary for his life, and will eteem his children as brothers, and (do they deire it) will teach them this my Art without any alary or Covenant. I will participate all my intructions, and Lectures and whatoever I know ele, to all mine own and my Maters
children, yea and to all my chollers, who hall in writing be bound to me, and tyed by a Phyical oath, and to none ele.

And as what concerns curing of the ick, I will to the uttermot of my power and judgement precribe them their diet, and will ecure them from all detriment and injury. I will not by any mans intreaties be moved to miniter poyon to any man, nor give any advice to do it. Neither will I give a woman any Phyick to make her micarry of her birth: but will ue mine Art and lead my life piouly and chatly. I will cut none for the tone, but leave that to skilful Chyrurgions. In what houe oever I come, it hall be for the good of the ick, and will abtain from offering any voluntary injury, epecially in any Veneral way to any uch as I hall have to cure, men or women, bond or free

Whatoever I hall ee or hear during my cure, yea though I were not called to give phyick, but as it were being in a common converation of life, if they be not things fitting to be revealed, I will conceal and keep them ecret to my elf. If I oberve this oath faithfully, may I thrive and proper in mine Art and Living, and grow famous to poterity. Or may the contrary happen to me upon breach of it.

div.head: The Aphorims of Hippocrates Prince of Phyicians.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This firt Section doth for the mot part handle the Dietary part of Phyicck, precribing not onely the meaure and obervation in meats and drinks for ound bodies, but alo for thoe that are ick and dieaed, with a moderation of Labour and Exercie.

div.head: APHORISM. 1.
div.p:
LIfe • is hort, the art is long, occaion uddain, experince dangerous, judgement difficult. Neither is it uffent that the Phyician doe his office, unles the Patient, and thoe which are attendants about him do their duty, and that outward
things be as well ordered, as thoe that are given inwardly.

p.hi: This Aphorim is as it were an Introduction or Proeme to the whole Work.

div.head: APH. 2.
div.p: In ditemperatures, loonees, Fluxes of the belly, and Vomitings which do com of their own accord if uch things be purged as ought to be purged, they are eaily endured, and are profitable, otherwie it falleth out contrary. In like ort if an emptying of veels be done as it hould be, it doth good as is eaily uffered, otherwie it doth work contrary effects. Wherefore conideration is to be had both of the region and the time, and alo of the age and the quality of the dieae for which uch things ought to be evacuated, or ele not.

p.hi:
For the Phyician ought in all
things to imitate and ait Nature.

div.head: APH. 3.
div.p: The full habit and tate of the bodies of wretlers, if it comes to the highet degree of fulnes is dangerous; for it cannot continue and remain in the ame tate, and when it cannot o remain nor grow into a better habit, it remains, that it mut needs decline into a wore. Wherefore that over full plight of body mut peedily be diolved, to the end it may take a beginning of new nourihment: Neither mut we proceed o far that the veels be quite empty, and void (for that is dangerous) but we mut proceed o far as Nature will bear and tolerate. So extreme evacuations are perilous, and extreme repletitions are likewie dangerous.

p.hi:
The former Aphorim was of the quality of humors to be evacuated
now this and thoe which follow, treat of the quantity.

div.head: APH. 4.
div.p: A mall and lender diet in long and lingering dieaes is always dangerous, and in harp dieaes likewie, when it is not convenient, and again diet reduced to extreme lendernes, is as full of peril, as extreme repletion, and fulnes in laborious and painful.

p.hi:
In this Aphorim Hippocrat ••
peaks, of the diet which fick men ought to ue.

div.head: APH. 5.
div.p:
The ick may offend in a lender diet, for thereby it happeneth that they grow wore, for every error in this cae is more dangerous, then in a omwhat fuller diet. For the ame caue, a very lender and too precie a diet, is omewhat dangerous to ound and healthful bodies, becaue they endure
the errors thereof with more difficulty. Wherefore a thin and exact manner of diet, for the mot part is more dangerous, then that which is a little more full and plentiful then hould be.

p.hi: He aith for the mot part; for Hippocrates meaning is not that a lender diet is abolutely hurtful.

div.head: APH. 6.
div.p: To extreme dieaes, extreme and exquiite remedies are bet.

p.hi: Extreme dieaes are call'd thoe which are mot harp and acute.

div.head: APH. 7.
div.p: When therefore the dieae is very harp and hath preently mot extreme paions and pains, we mut ue a mot exceeding lender diet when it is o. But when it is not o, we may ue a fuller diet, and as the dieae declineth, we may by little increae the diet.

p.hi:
By paions and pains he means
ymptomes, which in thee very harp dieaes are eldom but ac
• ompanied with hot Feavers.

div.head: APH. 8.
div.p: When the force of the dieae is greatet, then a mot paring diet is to be oberved.

p.hi: This Aphorim enjoyns that in general which the former doth give order to be done in ome particular dieaes.

div.head: APH. 9.
div.p: But we mut conider and conjecture by the ick man, whether he be able to hold out, and perit with the precribed diet, even to the tate and uttermot extremity of the dieae, or may faint or fail and being too weak with uch diet, may yield the victory to the dieae, before it retire, and be overcome.

For if the patient were able to indure without food, till the extre- <2 pages missing>
or coure: in the recoure of thoe fits, we mut ue abtinence.

p.hi: This Aphorim peaks of intermitting dieaes, which leave men for a eaon, and then return again.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p:
The fits and kinds of the dieaes, the eaons of the year, and the obervation of the alteration of the times of the fits return, if they come again every other day, or after a longer interval of time, will hew the harp invaions or extremities of the dieaes Likewie igns and tokens are taken from thoe things which appear afterwards, as for example in a Pluriie, if the corrupt matter, avoided by pitting, appear preently in the beginning, it declares the dieae will be but hort; but if it be longer before it do appear, it declareth a longer continuance of it. Moreover Urines, excrements
of the belly, and wets declare whither the dieaes will prove eaie, or difficult, hort or long.

p.hi: For if dieaes come in ummer, they will for the mot part proceed from choller, and the fits come every third day, and lat a hort time, if in wiuter they will proceed chiefly from Phlegm, the fits come every day and lat longer.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: Old men eaily endure fating, thoe who are in their declining age not o well, young men wore, and children wort of all, epecially thoe who are of a more lively pirit.

p.hi: Old when they are above 50 until 70, for thoe who are decrepit ought to feed often, but a little at a time.

div.head: APH. 14.
div.p:
Thoe bodies that grow, have
much natural heat, therefore they require great tore of food, or ele the body conumeth. But old men have little heat in them, therefore they require but a little food: for much nourihment extinguiheth that heat. And this is the reaon that old men have not very acute Feavers, becaue their bodies are not o hot.

p.hi: This Aphorim hews the reaons of the precedent, namely why old men can endure fating better then young men and children.

div.head: APH, 15.
div.p:
The venters by nature are mot hot in winter, and in the Spring, and leep mot long. Wherefore in thoe eaons more abundant food ought to be allowed, becaue they have mot natural heat; whereby it cometh to pas, tha •
they need more abundant food. Of which thing the differences of
ages, and wretlers bodies, are ufficient proofs.

p.hi: Venters are the tomach and bellie. And leep increaeth the natural heat.

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: Moit diet is good for all that are troubled with Agues, epecially for children and others who are accutomed to uch diet.

p.hi: Becaue Agues are dry, and becaue cutom is a kind of an acquired nature.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: We mut alo conider whom it may be convenient to feed once or twice a day, more or les, and by little and little: we mut attribute omething alo to cutom, age, eaon, and region.

p.hi:
Having before poken of the quantity and quality of food which may be given, he now peaks how it ought to be given, wherein he aith
cutom, time, country, and age ought to be conidered.

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p: Sick folk do mot hardly brook tore of meat in Summer, in Winter mot eaily, in the Spring time in a meaner manner.

p.hi: Here he expounds more particularly what he poke generally in the former Aphorim, and aith that in Summer they brook no tore of food, the reaon is becaue then the native heat is weak and languiheth, and in Autumn the bodies are obtructed, but in Winter, the Venters (namely the tomach and thoe parts) are very hot, and their leep is long, and in the Spring the natural heat evaporates more then in Wiuter.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p:
Nothing mut be given to them neither mut they be contrained to take meat, which have fits returning
at certain determined coures: but we ought to diminih food, before manifet tokens appeare to judge of the dieae.

p.hi: To the end that Nature may not be called away from its concoction and digetion.

div.head: APH. 20.
div.p: We ought not to move, alter, or change thoe things which are or jutly have been jutly determined by Nature, either with medicines or other procurements, but to let them alone.

p.hi: Becaue Nature by her determiation having hewn he is of herelf trong enough, needs no help of art.

div.head: APH. 21
div.p: Carry thoe things which are • o be drawn out thither whether they hall eem to encline and bend, by uch ways and places as are fittet for conveyance and expulion.

p.hi: If Nature be not able of her elf (as in the former Aphorim) to expel the caue of the dieae, then let Art help, to do it that way as Nature enclines.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p: We mut move with Medicine thoe things which are concocted and digeted, and not thoe which are raw and undigeted. Neither in the beginning of dieaes, unles they be provoked by their own force and violence, which very eldom cometh to pas.

p.hi: Nature after concoction doth egregate and expel humors; which if he be too languid to do, then it is good to help it with medicines.

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p:
Things evacuated and purged are not to be etimated by the¯ multitude, but adviedly to be conidered if thoe things be avoided and en • forth, which hould and <2 pages missing>
purged, which hould be, it doth good, and the ick may eaily uffer it, but if the contrary be evacuated, they do painfully endure it.

p.hi: Having in this latter part of this Section poken of purges given by Phyicians. He ets down this to put us again in mind of thoe purgations which come voluntarily from Nature. Having aid the ame thing of them in the econd Aphorim.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This econd Section, of which the univeral and plenary intention cannot well be aigned and et down, hath many things appertaining to the Doctrine of Ages, Signes, Nature, and Purgation.

div.head: APH. 1.
div.p: IF leep bring labour and pain in the dieae, it is a mortal ign: but if it bring eae and mitigation of pain, the ign is not deadly.

p.hi:
Sleep may hurt in two kindes: the one is common, when ick men leep in the beginning of their fits. The other is proper when they lelp
at any other times. Here we mut conceive he peaks of the lat.

div.head: APH. 2.
div.p: When a Delirium or raving is appeaed by leep, it is a good igne.

p.hi: This is an example of the univeral aertion in the preceding Aphorim, now the reaon of it is becaue nothing caueth and nouriheth raving more then want of leep; therefore if that caue it to ceae, it is a igne death is approaching.

div.head: APH. 3
div.p: Sleep and watching, if they be immoderate, and hall exceed a mean, are evil.

p.hi: For all immoderate things are enemies and advere to Nature, and too much leep is a ign that the brain is too cool and moit, and too little argues that it is too dry.

div.head: APH. 4.
div.p:
Neither atiety nor hunger,
neither any other thing which hall exceed the meaure of Nature, can be good or healthful.

p.hi: For health is defined to be a ymmetry and jut proportion, and beides too much fating fils the ventricle with evil humors.

div.head: APH. 5.
div.p: Wearines and dulnes proceeding of their own accord, ignifie dieaes to come.

p.hi: Namely uch a wearines as comes, without any immoderate exercie of the body.

div.head: APH. 6.
div.p: They which uffer pain of any part of the body, and do not in a manner feel it, have their undertanding ditempered and dieaed.

p.hi: That is to ay, have any dieae or ore which caueth pain, and they feel it not.

div.head: APH. 7.
div.p:
Bodies extenuated and wated
with long icknes, are to be retored and refrehed by little and little, but thoe which have been brought low quickly and in hort time, are ooner to be retored.

p.hi: For in thoe who are wated with long icknes, the fleh is wated; in thoe who are quickly brought low, the pirits onely, which may ooner be retored then the fleh.

div.head: APH. 8.
div.p: If any man eating meat after icknes, doth not recover trength it argues his body is burthened and oppreed with too much tore of food. But if the ame happen to one feeding meanly, we mut undertand that he hath need of evacuation.

p.hi: Becaue the body being oppreed with noxious humors, they hinder concoction, wherefore the aid humors mut firt be evacuated.

div.head: APH. 9.
div.p: How much the more thou halt nourih and cherih impure bodies, by o much the more thou halt harm and hurt them.

p.hi: This gives a reaon of the former Aphorim. Namely, becaue the aliment which you give to uch bodies increaes the quantity of vicious humors.

div.head: APH. 10.
div.p: He who will purge bodies, mut firt make them fluxible.

p.hi: Which may be done two ways, either by opening the paages, or by cutting off and extennating the thick humors.

div.head: APH. 11.
div.p: It is more eaie to be retored with drink then with meat.

p.hi: That is to ay with a liquid aliment, for that is ooner altered and ditributed then a olid, and if yet greater peed be required, they may be recreated with odours.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p: Thoe things which are left behind after the Cryis, are wont to bring forth relapes.

p.hi: Left becaue the matter was not fit to be expeld, or Nature was o weakened by icknes, that it was not able to expel all the noxious humors.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: The night which goeth before the fit or invaion is tedious, but the night following is commonly more eaie.

p.hi: We feel the pains of dieaes more by night, then by day, becaue in the day time, all the enes being awaked are imployed about ome other thing.

div.head: APH. 14.
div.p: The alteration of the excrements, not made to the wore part in fluxes of the belly is good.

p.hi:
Becaue it is a ign that thoe noxious
humors which by the excrements appeared to be in the body, are voided and gone.

div.head: APH. 15.
div.p: When the upper parts of the throat or gullet are ore or a breaking out of wheals doth arie in the body, it behoveth us to look upon the excrements, for if they be cholerick, the body is alo ick, but if they be like the excrements of ound perons, the body may be cherihed without danger.

p.hi: For if the excrements make no how of any further inward dieaes thoe wheals ignifie that Nature hath been trong enough of her elf to drive out the evil humors into thoe external parts of the body.

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: When hunger beareth way, we mut ret from much tirring or labour.

p.hi: For hunger and exercie together, would cat down trength, and dry up the bodie too much.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: When over much meat is received againt Nature, it caueth icknes as the manner of curing dieaes proceeding from repletion doth declare.

p.hi: Becaue it opprees Nature now thoe dieaes are cured by evacuation, which hews they were caued by repletion.

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p: Thoe thlngs which nourih peedily and plentifully, are quickly excreted and voided.

p.hi: For being peedily concocted and digeted the excrements mut alo of neceity have a peedy paage.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p: Praedictions of death or health in harp dieaes are not altogether certain.

p.hi: By reaon of the uddain changes which happen in them, according to the Nature of the humors; which caue thoe harp dieaes: and becaue the moletant humor runs out of one part into another.

div.head: APH. 20.
div.p: They which in young age have a moit and looe belly, in old age have it dry. But thoe who have it dry in their young age, have it moit when they are old.

p.hi: This Aphorim is to be undertood of thoe who continue in the ame diet when they are old, which they ued in their younger years, otherwie it would not be any way remarkable.

div.head: APH. 21.
div.p: Drinking of trong wine, putteth away hunger.

p.hi:
By hunger here is meant a dieae which is called Appetitus Caninus, or Appetentia Canina, and
thoe who are dieaed therewith can never be atisfyed, though they eat never o much.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p: Dieaes which are bred of atiety and urfeting are cured by evacuation and thoe which proceed from emptines are cured by fulnes, and o in the ret, contraries are the remedies of contraries.

p.hi: Neither mut thee contraries be ued in an extreme degree, for neither too much repletion nor too much evacuation can conveniently be endured.

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p: Acute and harp dieaes are judged within fourteen days.

p.hi: Though ome may be judged before, yet fourteen days is the uttermot day that can be expected for the judgement or Cryis of uch dieaes.

div.head: APH. 24
div.p: The fourth day is the Index of the eventh, the eighth the begining of the week following. Alo the eleventh day is to be conidered, for that is the fourth day of the econd week And again the eventeenth day is to be conidered, being the fourth from the fourteenth, and the eventh from the eleventh.

p.hi: He hath taught us that acute dieaes run out to a Cryis within fourteen days, which he here explains, and hews which are the Critical days for three weeks together.

div.head: APH. 25.
div.p: Summer Quartan Feavers are for the mot part hort: but the Autumnal long, epecially thoe which remain till Winter.

p.hi:
Becaue in Summer the uperfluous humors being driven into the outward parts of the body, are
quickly expelled through the pores, but they lat longer in Autumn, for they are ome way peculiar to that eaon, becaue by the forerunning Summer the faculties of the body are weakened, and in Winter by reaon that then the humors are thickened, and the pores hut up by the ambient cold. And this is but for the mot part, for ometimes it may prove otherways.

div.head: APH. 26.
div.p: It is better that a Feaver hould ucceed a Convulion, then Convulion a Feaver.

p.hi: For if a Convulion precede a Feaver, it proceeds from fulnes, which is eaily cured by evacuation, but if it ucceeds it proceeds from emptines, and is very dangerous for the Patient.

div.head: APH. 27.
div.p:
We ought not to be too confident if a harp dieae lacken
without any reaon. Neither much fear thoe dieaes which happen without any reaon. For mot of them are uncertain, and do not uually lat long.

p.hi: For if it lacken without reaon, it threatens a relape, and if it come without reaon, it is not much to be feared, for it will fall having no good foundation.

div.head: APH. 28.
div.p: If the body of thoe which have a harp Feaver abide all at one tay, and is nothing abated, or ele is melted and wated away beyond reaon, it is a very evil igne, for the firt doth ignifie a continuance of the dieae, and the latter a great imbecility of Nature.

p.hi:
For the firt is caued by a denity or thicknes of the skin, and thicknes and gluttinounes of humors, and the latter by a thinnes
or tenuity of the skin, and extenuation of humors which commonly is followed by imbecility of Nature.

div.head: APH. 29.
div.p: In the beginning of dieaes if there appears caue for moving of any thing; move it. But when they are in their tate it is far better to let it alone.

p.hi: The reaon of this Aphorim is laid down in the next.

div.head: APH. 30.
div.p:
Abo •• the beginnings and ends of di •• e • all things <…>
calm and remi •
in <…> d tate more vehement.

p.hi: This Aphorim is but the reaon of the precedent, and explains the formers and its own meaning.

div.head: APH. 31.
div.p: If the body thrive not with him who after a dieae feedeth well it is an evil ign.

p.hi:
For it ignifies one of thee two
things, namely that he takes more food, then Nature (yet weakened by icknes) can diget. Or that there is yet uch abundance of evil humors left in the ventricle and other parts of the body, that whatoever is put into it preently corrupts with them.

div.head: APH. 32.
div.p: Thoe which in the beginning of icknes feed much, and do not thrive therewith, for the mot part do at lat fall into a loathing of meat. On the contrary, thoe who in the beginning do vehemently abhor food, and afterwards deire much meat, are more eaily freed from their icknes.

p.hi:
Becaue feeding hard whilt there be yet reliques of evil humors remaining in the body, increaes the quantity of thoe evil humors, and o hinders their convalecencie. Whereas thoe who feed paringly in
the beginning oppres not the powers of Nature, which increaing do at lat expel thoe remainders of evil humors.

div.head: APH. 33.
div.p: In any dieae, if reaon be not weakened nor hurt, but that it is willing to embrace uch meats as are proffered it, it is good, but if it be otherwie it is evil.

p.hi: Becaue to have ones good undertanding ound, ignifies that the brain and all the nervous parts, with the Liver, Heart, and Ventricles are alo well affected, whereas if the Reaon be hurt, it ignifies that both the Brain and Ventricle are out of frame.

div.head: APH. 34.
div.p: They are not o dangerouly ick, to whoe nature, age, habit, or eaon, the dieae is familiar and agreeable; as they to whom the dieae is not agreeable to any of thoe things.

p.hi: By Nature here is meant the temperament of the body, by habit: whether a body be compoed of a oft and tender fleh, or of a thick and olid. Age, and eaon are eaie to be known what they mean, howoever for examples ake, acute Feavers are not common to old age, the body being then cold, and likely are deadly in old men. And what dieaes have mot affinity with each eaon of the year, is hewn in the third Section, the Aphorims 20, 21, 22, 23.

div.head: APH. 35.
div.p: It is better in any dieae that the parts adjoyning to the Navel and nethermot belly be omewhat thick and gros: for the extenuation and conumption of them is evil, and then it is not afe to miniter purgations working downward.

p.hi:
Becaue the thicknes and groenes
of thoe parts ignifie that the native heat is more valid, and the concoction better.

div.head: APH. 36.
div.p: Thoe which are endued with health of body, do quickly faint drinking a purging potion: and o do thoe which ue bad and corrupt nourihment.

p.hi: For in healthful men, the purging potion finding no vicious nor redundant humor to draw out and evacuate, doth firt diipate the pirits, then diolves thoe parts which are humid and moit, and finally corrupts thoe which are olid. And thoe which ue bad food have harp and biting humors, which being by the medicament driven through the enible parts of the body do caue fainting:

div.head: APH. 37.
div.p:
Thoe which are of ound and perfect health of body, do painfully
and grievouly endure purging medicines.

p.hi: This Aphorim is more general then the former, which expreed but one ymptome which befals ound men when they are purged. But this includes all the ret.

div.head: APH. 38.
div.p: Thoe meats and drinks which are wore, yet pleaant, are to be preferred before thoe which are better, but yet unpleaant and ditating.

p.hi: Becaue they pleae the Patient bet, and becaue the Ventricle doth more greedily embrace, and peedilier concoct thoe meats and drinks which are pleaant.

div.head: APH. 39.
div.p: For the mot part old men are not o often ick as young are: But being once taken with long dieaes they commonly dye.

p.hi:
Old men are preumed to be more
dicreet and temperate in their feeding which is the caue of this aertion for thoe which are not o, are more ubject to icknes then young men, being weaker then they.

div.head: APH. 40.
div.p: Rheums decending down to the mouth, and falling down to the throat do not come to concoction in thoe which are very old.

p.hi: This is as it were an example of the latter aertion of the precedent Aphorim, namely that old men once taken with long dieae commonly dye.

div.head: APH. 41.
div.p: They dye uddenly which do often, and vehemently woun and faint without any manifet caue.

p.hi: Becaue it argueth an imbecility of the vital faculty.

div.head: APH. 42.
div.p:
It is impoible to cure a vehement
Apoplexie and very hard to cure a weak one.

p.hi: For all Apoplexies are caued by a topping of the animal Faculties from decending any lower into the body then the head.

div.head: APH. 43.
div.p: Strangled & uffocated folk, being not as yet dead, do not return to themelves, if there appear any foam about their mouth.

p.hi: Becaue it is a ign that the Lights are violently wronged.

div.head: APH. 44.
div.p: Thoe which are very gros by Nature, do enjoy horter life then thoe which are lean.

p.hi: Becaue fat mens native heat is weaker then lean mens.

div.head: APH. 45.
div.p: Change and alteration of place, and diet, and epecially of age, free children from the falling evil.

p.hi: For when they come to their youthful age they are cured by their hot and dry temperament.

div.head: APH. 46.
div.p: Of two pains at one time, not poeing the elf-ame place, that which is the mot vehement, doth dull the pain of the other.

p.hi: It doth neither cure nor expel the other, but onely dull and obcure it.

div.head: APH. 47.
div.p: Whiles filthy and corrupt matter is digeting, pains and Agues do rather happen, then when it is come to maturation

p.hi: For when it is maturated the inflammation and burning ceaeth.

div.head: APH. 48.
div.p: In every exercie of the body, when it beginneth to be wearied, ret doth preently mitigate the wearines.

p.hi:
For as he aid in the two and
twentieth Aphorim of this Section, one contrary is the cure of the other.

div.head: APH. 49
div.p: Thoke who are accutomed to daily labours, although they be weak or old men, do more eaily endure accutomed exercies, then thoe who are not accutomed to them, although they be trong and young

p.hi: Becaue cutom is a econd nature

div.head: APH. 50.
div.p: Things accutomed a long time, although they be wore are wont to be les grievous, then thoe which are unaccutomed, wherefore alo a change is not to be made to unaccutomed things.

p.hi: Becaue the bodies are ubject to changes, therefore upon uch changes we mut alo fall upon ome unaccutomed diet.

div.head: APH. 51.
div.p: It is danderous at one time, much and uddainly, either to empty, fill, heat or cool, or by any other means to move or tir the body. For any thing paing the bonnds of mediocrity is an enemy to Nature, and that is afe which is done by little and little, and epecially when an alteration and change is to be made from one thing to another.

p.hi: Namely from accutomed to unaccutomed.

div.head: APH. 52.
div.p: He mut not pas forthwith from one medicine to another, when all things fall not out o well as they hould, to him; who doth proceed by good reaon; o that remain till and continue which eemed to him to be o from the Beginning.

p.hi:
For it is no point of widom lightly
to recede from that which once you have approved of, though it doth not preentely work as you would have it.

div.head: APH. 53.
div.p: Thoe which have a moit belly, pas their youthful age more eaily then thoe which have the ame dry: but they pas their old age more hardly and with more difficulty, for when they wax old, for the mot part it is dryed.

p.hi: This Aphorim is of it elf plain enough, and compared with the 20 Aphorim of this Section, they expound one another.

div.head: APH. 54.
div.p: Greatnes and tallnes of body is comely to the tate of young age: but to old age it is improfitable, and wore then a hort tature.

p.hi: For it burdeneth old men, and makes them go tooping and crookbacked.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This third book is almot reduced to the dicoure of ages or times, expreing unto us two common places, that is to ay the trength and force of ages, and the diverity of dieaes throughout thoe ages, and times.

div.head: APHORISM. 1.
div.p: ALteration and variablenes of the eaons, do mot epecially bring forth dieaes, and likewie great alterations of cold and heat in thoe eaons, and of other things anwering to them in proportion.

p.hi: Becaue they alter the air which we draw in continually with our breaths.

div.head: APH. 2.
div.p: Some natures are well or ill affected in Summer, and ome in Winter.

p.hi: By natures he means the temperatures: and of them the cold and moit temperatures fare bet in Summer, and the hot and dry wort.

div.head: APH. 3.
div.p: Some dieaes are well or ill affected, ome more to one time, and ome to another, and ome ages more to ome one time, place and kind of dyet then they are to another.

p.hi: He now affirms that to be true in dieaes and ages, which he had in the precedent Aphorim aerted in temperatures of the body.

div.head: APH. 4.
div.p: Autumnal dieaes are to be expected in thoe eaons, when on the elf-ame day it is ometimes hot, and ometimes cold.

p.hi: For not the names but the temperatures of the eaons, are the caues of dieaes.

div.head: APH. 5.
div.p: The South wind dulleth the hearing, obcureth and darkneth the ight, offendeth the head with aches and rheumes, procureth and caueth heavines and faintnes in the members. When therefore it is frequent and bloweth often, uch things are incident to the weak and ickly. Contrariwie the North wind caueth coughs, exaperateth and excoriateth the jaws, hardens the belly, uppreeth Urine, tirs up cold hiverings and hakings, ingendereth the pains of the ides and breat. Therefore when this wind bears way thoe that are weak and feeble mut, look for uch accidents.

p.hi:
The South wind by reaon of its hot and moit Nature, and the north
wind becaue of its cold and drynes do work thee effects in weak bodies.

div.head: APH. 6.
div.p: When the Summer is like the Spring time, we mut expect much weating in Agues.

p.hi: Becaue by its temperate and moderate heat, it draws the humidities of the body to the skin, but cannot diolve them into vapors.

div.head: APH. 7.
div.p: Sharp Agues are ingendred by great drought and drynes, and if the year prove to be for the mot part uch; as the tate of the eaon is, uch kinds of dieaes for the mot part mut be o expected.

p.hi: Sharp Agues are thoe which quickly end, but have heavy and troubleome ymptomes.

div.head: APH. 8.
div.p:
In certain & moderate times, oberving their eaonablenes, certain
and eaonable dieaes having a happy determination are ingendred. But in uncertain and immoderate times, uncertain dieaes are ingendred; and evil to be judged.

p.hi: For dieaes follow the nature of the efficient caues, and the efficient caues are likely uch as the temperature of the year is.

div.head: APH. 9.
div.p: In Autumn univerally there are mot harp and deadly dieaes: but the pring time is mot wholeom, and free from deadly dieaes.

p.hi:
The reaons whereof are, firt by reaon of its ineqnality, the mornings and evenings being cold and the midday hot. Secondly, becaue the preceding Summer hath made the humors adut. Thirdly; becaue the aid Summer hath weakened the forces. Fourthly, becaue the
morning and evenings ambient coldnes drives the vicious humors into the body. And fiftly, becaue there is abundance of fruits eaten in that eaon, the eating of which breeds tore of evil humors.

div.head: APH. 10.
div.p: Autumn is hurtful to uch as are in a conumption.

p.hi: By reaon of its drynes, coldnes, and inequality.

div.head: APH. 11.
div.p: Amongt the parts of the year if the Winter be extraordinary dry, and the Spring very rainy, and ubject to outherly winds. It mut of neceity fall out that in Summer, harp Agues, Rheums in the Eys and Bloody-fluxes do happen, epecially to women and men who are of a moit nature.

p.hi: By reaon of the abundance of humors which are ubject to putrefaction.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p: Contrarily if Winter be Southernly, full of rain and warm, and the Spring dry and northernly, women whoe child-birth and deliverance happeneth neer the Spring, do upon the leat occaion uffer abortment and untimely birth: or if they be delivered at their due time, they bring forth uch weak and dieaed children, that either they die quickly, or live but weakly and ickly. To others there happen bloody-fluxes and hot inflammations of the eys, and to old men rheums which hortly kill them.
This Aphorims meaning is plain enough now, the particular caues why thee everal dieaes happen are et down at large in GalensComments to which we refer the Reader.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: Summer being dry and the wind northernly, Autumn full of rain and the wind outhernly, vehement pains of the head are to be expected in the Winter following. Alo coughs, hoarnees, & rheums, ditillings at the notrils, and to ome pining Conumptions.

p.hi: Having in the preceding Aphorims poken of the Winter and Spring, he now peaks of the other two eaons, namely Summer and Autumn.

div.head: APH. 14.
div.p: A northernly and dry Autumn is profitable and good to men which are of a moit temperature, and alo to women, to others it caueth hot inflammations in the eys, and Feavers partly harp, and partly long, and ome alo are troubled with Melancholly.

p.hi: This Aphorim ought to be annexed to the former as part of it.

div.head: APH. 15.
div.p: Of all the eaons throughout the whole yeer, drynes and droughts are more wholom and les dangerous to mans life, then daily howers of rain and moiture
This Aphorim by right hould have been placed after the 17th of this Section, and the 17 after the 5, as Galen hews in his Comment upon this preent Aphorim.

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: When there is much rain thee dieaes for the mot part are ingendred, namely long contlnuing Agues, Fluxes of the belly, corruption of humors, Falling-icknes, Apoplexies, Squinancies But when there is much drought there happen Conumptions, Rheumes in the eys, pains of the joynts, difficulty in making Urine, and paions of the intetines or inward parts.

p.hi: This Aphorim is as it were an explication of the former, by which ome ignorant men might infer that in a dry year, there would be no dieaes at all ingendred.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: Daily eaons of weather being northernly do cloe and trengthen the body and make it nimble, well coloured and quick of hearing. They dry and harden the belly, but bite and offend the eys, and if any pain have poet the breat, they make it more grievous Contrariwie outhernly eaons looe and moiten the body, and weakens it, dull the hearing, caue heavines, and giddines of the head, mitines and dimnes of the eys, dulnes and lazines of the body, and make the belly looe and laxative.

p.hi: For the northern wind is cold and dry: and the outhern hot and moit.

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p: As touching eaons of the year in the Spring and beginning of Summer, children and thoe which are neeret to them in age, live in very good health; in Summer and ome part of Autumn old men live bet, but in the ret of Autumn and Winter they of a middle age.

p.hi: Summer is good for old men by reaon of the frigidity of their nature, Winter for men in the trength of their age, becaue it abates and is contrary to their bilious temper.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p: Any dieaes, are ingendred in any times of the year, yet many are rather caued, and tirred, in ome one more then in another.

p.hi: Intending in the following Aphorims to et down what dieaes are peculiar to everal times of the year he promies this as a general one.

div.head: APH. 20.
div.p: In the Spring there happeneth madnes, melancholly, falling-evil, fluxes of blood, the quinancy, rheumes, ditillations of humors, coughs, leproies, dry cabs, morphues, and many ulcerous wheals, puhes, and pains of the joynts.

p.hi: Which dieaes for the mot part being not dangerous, but rather conducing to health by driving out noxious humors out of the inward to the outward parts of the body; this Aphorim rather confirms then oppoes the latter part of the ninth Aphorim.

div.head: APH. 21
div.p:
In Summer there are ome of thoe dieaes before poken of; in the Spring alo continual Feavers and burning Agues, and many Tertians, and Quartans, Vomitings, Fluxes of the belly, inflammations of the eys, pains of the
ears, ulcerations of the mouth, putrefactions of the genitals, and weatings,

p.hi: Namely in the beginning of Summer are incident ome of thoe dieaes which were alo towards the latter end of the Spring, for it being of the ame temperature they mut ingender the ame dieaes.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p: Alo many Summer dieaes are in Autumn, both Quartans and uncertain wandring Agues, wellings of the Spleen, Hydropie, Conumptions, Strangury Looenes & excoriations of the bowels, aches of hucle-bone, Squinancies, hortnees of breath, treight preings or drawing together of the bowels in ome part of them; the Falling-icknes, madnes, and melancholly.

p.hi:
The beginning of Autumn, and end of Summer have the ame affinity
as the beginning of Summer and end of the Spring.

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p: In Winter are ingendred Pluriies, inflammations of Lungs Lethargie, Rheums in the notrils, hoarnes, coughs, pains of the breats, ides, and loyns, headaches, wimmings and giddinees of the head (cauing dimnes to the eys) and Apoplexies.

p.hi: This and the precedent Aphorims concerning eaons, are to be undertood when eaons do hold their own order and temperature.

div.head: APH. 24
div.p: But as concerning ages, thee dieaes do happen to little children and lately born; Ulcers in the mouth, Vomiting, Coughs, want of leep, great fears, inflammations of the Navil, moit runings at the ears.

p.hi:
Having poken of the eaons of
dieaes he now ets down in what ages uch and uch dieaes ue to happen, beginning with infants newly born.

div.head: APH. 25.
div.p: The time of Teeth-breeding coming, there happen itching of the gums, Feavers, Convulions, Fluxes of the belly, epecially when they bring forth their dogteeth, and epecially thoe children chiefly that are mot fat, and have their belly bound.

p.hi: Which time of teeth breeding begins commonly at even moneths of age, and ometimes at four: the dogteeth at a year or ten moneths.

div.head: APH 26.
div.p:
When children begin to be a little elder, they are ubject to the inflammations of the Almonds of the mouth, dilocation of the turning joynts in the nape of the neck inwardly, hortnes of wind,
breeding of the Stone, round-worms, gut-worms, long hanging warts, Satyrams, Stranguries Scrophules in the neck and other riings, epecially thoe before declared

p.hi: Now he ets down thoe dieaes which children are ubject to after they are pat teeth-breeding, to twelve or fourteen years of age.

div.head: APH. 27.
div.p: Moreover to thoe which are greater and coming to ripe age, there happen many of thoe former dieaes, but more long continuing Agues, and fluxes of blood at the notrils.

p.hi: This Aphorim concerns children about twelve, thirteen, or fourteen years of age, and ripenes of age comes ooner or later according to the beat or coldnes of contitutions.

div.head: APH. 28.
div.p:
The dieaes of children for the
mot part, ome of them attain to the Cryis or alteration within 40 days, ome within even moneths, ome within even years, others when they come to ripe age. But thoe which hall continue longer, and hall neither be diolved, in men children when they come to be about fourteen yeers or fifteen or maiden children when their monethly terms do break forth, do ue to lat a long time.
Or as Heurnius aith in his Comments, do lat as long as they live.

div.head: APH. 29.
div.p: To young men there doth happen pitting of blood, Conumptions, harp Feavers, falling-icknees and other dieaes, but epecially thee we have now reheared.

This age according to Heurniusis when their voice breaks and they begin to peak big.
<2 pages missing>
notrils, dimnes of ight, Glaucoma, and dullnes of hearing.

p.hi: Here by old men he means thoe who have attained to their lat age.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This fourth Section is variable, but for the mot part is reduced to evacuation and prognotick igns of future events.

div.head: APHORISM. 1.
div.p: THou halt purge child-bearing women if it be needful, at the fourth moneth after conception, and o unto the eventh, but thoe more paringly: but the conception being younger, or elder, thou halt abtain.

p.hi:
Becaue in thoe moneths the ligaments wherewith the conception is fatened to the womb, are tronget and thicket, and not ca • e to be
broken by the commotions of purging medicines.

div.head: APH. 2.
div.p: Such things are to be drawn out of the body by the ue of purging medicines, as they are, which iuing out of their own accord would do good to it. But thoe which iue out in a contrary manner are to be topped.

p.hi: For it is good in artificial purges to imitate Nature.

div.head: APH. 3
div.p: If uch things be purged as hould be it is good, and the Patient doth eaily endure it. But if you do otherwie, the patient doth indure it painfully.

p.hi: This Aphorim being the ame with the 2 and 25 of the firt Section, it needs no further explication, and ome have in this place left it quite out.

div.head: APH. 4.
div.p: In Summer it is more convenient to purge the upper Venters, in Winter the inferior by tool.

p.hi: For in Summer choller is the predominant humor, and naturally by reaon of the ambient heat all things are carried upwards, o it is bet to purge by Vomit.

div.head: APH. 5.
div.p: Under the Canicular or Dogtar, and before it, purgations are painful and difficult.

p.hi: Becaue the ambient heat eeks to draw the humors outwards by weat while the purgation forces them out by tool.

div.head: APH. 6.
div.p: Lean and lender men are eaily provoked to Vomit, and therefore mut be purged by vomit, unles it be in Winter.

p.hi:
For lender men are for the mot part chollerick, which choller if
they have a facility in vomiting hould be purged upward, unles it be in Winter, for then the inferior venters mut be purged by tool.

div.head: APH. 7.
div.p: Purge thoe which do not vomit eaily, and are in good plight, downwards by tool, o it be not Summer.

p.hi: For at any other time of the year you may ecurely do it.

div.head: APH. 8.
div.p: Do not purge them upwar • s which are ubject to a Conumption or Phtyick.

p.hi: For fear of hurting the intrumental parts of repiration which are weak.

div.head: APH. 9.
div.p: Thou halt purge melancholly folk trongly by tool, in like manner beginning the contrary way of purging.

p.hi:
For light matter bending upward,
mut be drawn out by the upper parts, but the heavier and groer matter by the lower parts.

div.head: APH. 10.
div.p: We mut purge in very harp icknees, if the matter do move to the purging of it; and that the very ame day wherein the icknes doth begin; for delay in uch dieaes is very hurtful and dangerous.

p.hi: Before the trength of body fail, or diminih, or the aguih heat increae, or the humors which wander up and down the body ettle about ome principal part.

div.head: APH. 11.
div.p: Thoe which have gripings and wringings in the belly, and horrible pain about the navel and the loyns, and cannot be eaed and diolved by medicine or otherwie, they will fall into a dry Dropie.

p.hi: Which is called a Timpany.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p: Thoe are not to be purged in Winter by vomit, whoe tomack and belly cannot retain meat until it be digeted

p.hi: He means uch purges as are general and purge the whole body; for in particular purges you may do otherwie. As if we would onely eae the ventricle of phlegm, we may do it by vomit in Winter. And by the ame reaon, if yellow choller be in the intetines only, we may in Summer purge it out by tool.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: Their bodies are to be made moit before hand with plenty of food, and with eae and ret; who taking a potion of Hellebor do hardly and painfully vomit.

p.hi:
Becaue if the nerves and other dry parts of the body be not moitened the Hellebor which is hot and dry
in the third degree, and is very drawing, may caue deadly Convulions

div.head: APH. 14.
div.p: Hellebor being drunk, the body ought rather to be moved, then yielded to leep or ret: For the ayling in a hip doth manifet, that our bodies are provoked and t • irred by motion.

p.hi: And eeing that motion of it elf provokes the body to vomit, much more will it do it, with the help of a medicine. And ret keeps the body in the ame tate, motion changes and alters it.

div.head: APH. 15.
div.p: If you will have Hellebore to work more forcibly move and tir the body, but when you will tay it, procure leep and do not move.

p.hi:
For ince motion ets it more violently a working, ret mut needs caue it to tay, eeing contrary operations
work contrary effects.

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: Hellebor is very dangerous to them which have a healthful body, for it ingendreth Convulions.

p.hi: For it is one of its chief qualities to caue ditentions, o finding no excrements in the body it falls upon the olid parts, and epecially the nerves.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: If he which hath not an Ague doth loath his meat, hath a gnawing of the mouth or the tomack, a darkom giddines of the brain, and bitternes of the mouth, it ignifieth that he had need to be purged upwards.

p.hi: For thee are three ymptomes by which the Phyician may know the Patient hath need of being purged upward.

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p:
Whooever having need of
hath pains above the Middriff, it is a ign he mut be purged upwards, but the pains which are under the ame, hew a purging downwards to be needful.

p.hi: For which way the humor naturally deires to go, that way you mut by the help of medicines end it.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p: Thoe which do not thirt while they are purged by a medicinal potion, hall not leave purging while they do thirt.

p.hi: Becaue the excrements being evacuated, the mouth of the ventricle is dryed up which caueth thirt.

div.head: APH. 20.
div.p: If there be gripings about the Navel without a Feaver, and heavines of the knees, and pain of the loyns, they ignifie that there is need of purging downward.

p.hi:
Becaue that all thee ymptomes
hew that the noxious humors motion and violence is downward.

div.head: APH. 21.
div.p: Black excrements of the belly like unto black blood, coming forth of their own accord, both with a Feaver, or without, are mot evil, and by how much the more the evil colours are, o much the wore, the excrements are. But uch things to be expelled out by a medicine is far better, and that by how much the more colours there hall be.

p.hi: For if they come out of their own accord it hews there are many ill affected humors in the body, which driven out by Phyick the body remains ound.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p: In the beginning of any dieae if black choller come forth either above or beneath it is deadly.

p.hi:
For it ignifies that nature is ill
affected, which never evacuates uperfluous things till they be concocted, wherefore if black choller come forth in the beginning of a dieae, it is evacuated by its proper malice and not by the law of Nature.

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p: Thoe which are pined or brought low by harp or long dieaes, or by wounds, or any other means, and do void black choller or as it were black blood, do dye the next day following.

p.hi: Namely through the imbecility of faculty, and greatnes of the dieae.

div.head: APH. 24.
div.p: A Bloody flux if it proceed from black choller is mortal.

p.hi:
Becaue it ulcerates the entrails with an ulcered cancer, which can hardly be cured in the outward parts, to which medi caments may be applyed; therfore much les there
where no uch medicaments can be applyed.

div.head: APH. 25.
div.p: For blood to be carried upward of what kind oever it be, is an evil ign, but if black blood be avoided downwards it is good.

p.hi: For if it be carried upwards, it hews there is ome veel opened, extended, or broken in the upper parts. And in this place by carrying upward is meant through the mouth, not through the notrils, which for the mot part is good.

div.head: APH. 26.
div.p: If any man being afflicted with a bloody-flux, void as it were little pieces of fleh, it is a mortal ign.

p.hi: For then the exulceration is o great that it can no way be healed.

div.head: APH. 27.
div.p:
To thoe which have tore of blood flowing from what part oever, in Feavers, their bodies become
come moit after they have been refrehed.

p.hi: Becaue the natural heat is weakened by tore of blood flowing, and though here mention be made onely of Feavers, yet it holds in other dieaes likewie.

div.head: APH. 28.
div.p: Thoe which avoid chollerick excrements downward, if deafnes come thereupon, they ceae from avoiding them. And thoe which are affected with deafnes are cured of it by avoiding of chollerick excrements.

p.hi: He means not a permanent deafnes, for that is not o cured, but of a tranitory or upervening deafnes caued by cholerick humors moleting the brain, which mut needs ceae when they come down.

div.head: APH. 29.
div.p:
If cold hakings happen, to them that are ick of an Ague,
the ixt day they have a difficult Cryis, and we cannot well judge of the dieae

p.hi: Becaue for the mot part they preage either death or return of the dieae.

div.head: APH. 30.
div.p: In them which are afflicted with fits of Agues, whenoever the Ague hall leave them, if it return the ame hour the next day it is wont to have a difficult Cryis, and determination.

p.hi: That is to ay it will not eaily be diolved.

div.head: APH. 31.
div.p: Impothumes are caued neer the joynts, and epecially neer the jaw-bones, or mandibles to them which feel wearines or laitude in Feavers.

p.hi:
Becaue the heat of the Feaver having drawn the humors up into the head, when they fall down again
the jaw-bones being very weak cannot expel them to other parts of the body, but there they mut ret. And the joynts heated by motion attract the humors of the body.

div.head: APH. 32.
div.p: Thoe which recovering from a dieae have a pain in ome place hal have Impothumes or botches in that place.

p.hi: He peaks of uch as recover and yet have ome reliques of feaverih matter remaining in their bodies.

div.head: APH. 33.
div.p: If any part be pained before the dieae, there is the eat of the dieae.

p.hi: Therefore if it be a principal part, we mut indeavor to divert the humors from thence.

div.head: APH. 34.
div.p:
If a uffocation of the breath do happen upon a uddain to one afflicted with a Feaver, no welling
appearing in the jaws or gullet, it is deadly.

p.hi: For it is a ign that Phlegm toppeth his breath and repiration, without which he cannot live.

div.head: APH. 35.
div.p: If to one afflicted with a Feaver the neck be uddainly turned awry, and he can carce wallow, and no welling appear it is deadly

p.hi: For it hews there is an inflammation in the mucles lying before the throat, or in the throat it elf.

div.head: APH 36.
div.p: Sweats are good to thoe who are ick of an Ague, if they iue forth the third, fifth, eventh, ninth eleventh, fourteenth, eventeenth, one and twentieth, thirty, and four and thirtieth days, for thoe weats work the diolution of the dieae: thoe which happen otherwie ignifie pain and length of the dieae, or a return of the ame.

p.hi: For thee are the onely days of Critical weats, in which we may be judge of the d • olution of the dieae.

div.head: APH. 37.
div.p: Cold weats with a harp Feaver betoken death, but with a milde and gentle Ague, length of the dieae.

p.hi: Becaue it hews that the Patients body doth o much abound in cold humors, that neither the natural, nor the harp Feavers heat is able to heat them.

div.head: APH. 38
div.p: In what part of the body the the weat is, there is the dieae.

p.hi: Becaue in that part, tick the redundant and noxious humors.

div.head: APH. 39.
div.p: And in what part of the body there is heat or cold, there the the dieae is etled.

p.hi:
Namely in an exceive manner,
and not proceeding from any external caue, for it hews a ditemperature contrary to health.

div.head: APH. 40.
div.p: And when alterations do happen in the whole body, and it is ometimes cool, and ometimes hot, or one colour aries after another, it ignifies continuance of the dieae.

p.hi: Becaue Nature cannot in a hort time concoct and ubdue everal defects or dieaes.

div.head: APH. 41.
div.p: Much weating caued through leep without any manifet outward caue, ignifies that the body is fed with tore of food. But if this happen to one that feeds paringly, it hews that the body wants evacuation.

p.hi: By reaon of the evil humors and excrements which are the caues of that weating.

div.head: APH. 42.
div.p: When there is much weat cold or hot always iuing forth, the cold ignifies a longer, the hot a horter dieae.

p.hi: Becaue it hews the matter to be thin, which nature can eaily concoct and hake off.

div.head: APH. 43.
div.p: Continual Feavers which afflict every third day more vehemently, and do not ceae are the more dangerous, but if they ceae and paue in any manner, they ignifie that there is no preent danger.

p.hi: For it heweth the Phlegm doth not trouble any noble part, and that no venemous force hath laid iege to any principal part. And natural trength doth recollect it elf during the intermiion of the Feaver.

div.head: APH. 44.
div.p:
Swellings and pains about the joynts are caued to them who
are afflicted with long Agues.

p.hi: By the humors et •• ng in thoe places, unles they be carried away by a thick white urine making.

div.head: APH. 45.
div.p: Thoe which have wellings and pains of the joynts after long Ague, feed over liberally.

p.hi: For the dieae being gone, no other reaon can be given for this redundancy of humors.

div.head: APH. 46.
div.p: If a cold hivering fit, the Feaver being without intermiion, do aail the ick man being already weak, it is a deadly ign.

p.hi: For it hews nature to be o far pent, that it is able onely to tir, but not to thrut out the excrement; or if it doth, the ick man fainteth therewith.

div.head: APH. 47.
div.p:
Excrements avoided in Feavers not intermittent, by vomit,
or pitting, if they be of a leaden colour, bloody, tinking, or cholerick, they are all evil: but if they come forth conveniently they are good

p.hi: Leaden colour becaue they ignifie a mortification of thoe parts from whence they come; bloody becaue they ignifie an opening of ome veels. Stinking becaue they ignifie putrifaction. Ch • lerick becaue they tetifie abundance of choller.

div.head: APH. 48.
div.p: In continual Feavers, if the exterior parts be cold, and the inward burn, and the Patient be thirty, it is a deadly ign.

p.hi: Becaue the • eat of that inward part draws all the blood to it, whereby the heart is oppreed.

div.head: APH. 49
div.p:
In continual Feavers, if the lip, eye, brows, or noe be turned aawry,
if the ick man do not ee nor hear, which oever of thee hall happen, the body being weak, death is neer at hand.

p.hi: For all thee are igns that the moving animal faculty uffereth.

div.head: APH. 50.
div.p: If there happeneth in a continual Feaver defficulty and hardnis of breathing, with delirium and doting, thee igns are deadly.

p.hi: Becaue it ignifies that both the brain, and the intruments of breathing do uffer.

div.head: APH. 51.
div.p: Apothumes in Feavers which are not diolved in the firt Cryis or judgement ignifie length of the dieae.

p.hi: Becaue they hew that there is a multitude of noxious humors, which nature could not expel at one Cryis.

div.head: APH. 52.
div.p:
It is not aburd to weep and hed
tears in Feavers and other dieaes voluntarily, but to weep againt the will is very aburd and inconvenient.

p.hi: Becaue that weeping againt the will hews a weaknes and imbecility in the retentive faculty.

div.head: APH. 53.
div.p: They have fierce and vehement Feavers, who have a tough, and clammy moiture about their teeth in thoe Feavers.

p.hi: For thoe clammy moitures cannot grow there o abundantly without exceive heat which dries up the pituitous humor.

div.head: APH. 54.
div.p: Thoe who have long lating dry coughs, in burning Feavers, which do not provoke much, are not wont to be very thirty.

p.hi:
For by that motion which is made in coughing, there is ome humidity drawn from thoe places which are
adjoyning to the rough artery.

div.head: APH. 55.
div.p: All Feavers proceeding from tumors in the groyn, and other adenous parts are evil, except diary Feavers which lat but one day.

p.hi: For thoe Feavers come when thoe tumors are caued by ome outward thing, as ome blow or the like, and not by any inward inflammation.

div.head: APH. 56.
div.p: Sweat coming often upon one ick of an Ague not ceaing, is evil, for the dieae is prolonged, and it ignifieth that there is much moiture.

p.hi: Which abundance of moiture asketh nature much time to concoct and dipere.

div.head: APH 57.
div.p: If o • e have Convulions, or Cramps, a Feaver coming diolveth them:

p.hi: Becaue the Feaver doth heat, extenuate, and hake off thoe cold humors which filled up the nervous parts.

div.head: APH 58.
div.p: If a cold haking fit doth come upon him which hath a burning Feaver, it diolveth it.

p.hi: For a burning Feaver being caued by choller putrifying in the veins, and a cold haking, by the cholers being wiftly carryed about the enible parts of the body, it hews that the choler is come out of the veins, to the skin.

div.head: APH. 59.
div.p: An exquiite and perfect Tertian Feaver cometh to his Cryis or tate, in even circuits or fits, at the utmot.

p.hi: An exquiite Tertian is that which is caued by yellow choler carried up and down the enible parts of the body, keeping its nature pure and incere.

div.head: APH. 60.
div.p: Thoe that wax deaf and thick of hearing through Feavers, are delivered from it, by flux of blood at the noe, or by the belly.

p.hi: It is no marvel if dieaes ceae, when the noxious humors are tranlated or carried away.

div.head: APH. 61.
div.p: Unles the Feaver leave the patient in the odd days, it is accutomed to return again.

p.hi: If this Aphorim hould peak of all Feavers it were fale: if of acute and continual Feavers it is true.

div.head: APH. 62.
div.p: Thoe which have the yellow Jaundie upon Agues before the eventh day have an evil ign.

p.hi: Becaue the yellow Jaundies proceeds from the inflammation of the Liver.

div.head: APH. 63.
div.p:
Thoe Feavers which have their
haking fits every day are every day diolved.

p.hi: Yet there remains ome fire wherby the paroxim is renewed.

div.head: APH. 64.
div.p: It is a good thing for them which have the yellow-Jaundies coming on them in Feavers on the 7 day, ninth, eleventh, or fourteenth, unles the right Hypocondrium be hard, for then it is evil.

p.hi: For the Hypocondrium being hard ignifies there is an inflammation of the Liver.

div.head: APH. 65.
div.p: In Feavers a vehement heat about the Stomach, and a gnawing about the heart is bad.

p.hi: Becaue it ignifies an ebullition of choler in the tunicles of the ventricle or tomach.

div.head: APH. 66
div.p: Convulions and vehement pains about the bowels in harp Feavers are evil.

p.hi: For vehement Feavers dry and tretch the nerves like fire, and by the ame vehemence of heat and drought, the bowels are pained.

div.head: APH 67.
div.p: In feavers great fears or Convulions after leep do prognoticate evil.

p.hi: For fears ignifie the repletion of the head with melancholy humors and Convulions, abundance of phlegmatick humors.

div.head: APH. 68.
div.p: The breath not keeping its due coure, is evil: for it doth ignifie convulion.

p.hi: Caued by the over-drying of the mucles and nerves which move the tomack

div.head: APH. 69.
div.p:
Urines in a Feaver being thick, clotted, and little in quantity, do profit them that make them, if afterwards, thin urine, and much
in quantity be avoided by them. But thoe urines mot commonly become uch, in which the hypotais or ediment hal appear preently after they are made, or not long after.

p.hi: Becaue the gros humors cauing the Feaver are expelled in the humor, which makes the urine which comes afterwards to be thin in repect of that.

div.head: APH 70.
div.p: Thoe who have their water troubled or unclean in Agues, uch as are the waters of Cattel, have or hall have head-aches.

p.hi: Becaue the windy or flatuous pirit is eaily drawn up into the head together with heat.

div.head: APH. 71.
div.p:
Thoe which hall have their Cryis or alteration of the dieae the eventh day, have a little red cloud in the urine the fourth day,
<1 page duplicate>
and other things thereunto belonging accordingly.

p.hi: Thee red clouds are eldom een, though the white be frequent, and are both of them igns of concoction.

div.head: APH. 72.
div.p: Urines very cleer and white are bad, epecially in thoe who are afflicted with phrenies.
Becaue uch urines are igns of an extreme crudity. And Galen aith he never knew any one who was afflicted with a phrenie, and made uch water, aved.

div.head: APH. 73.
div.p: Thoe which have an inflation of the Hypoco • dria, and a rumbling pain of the loyns ucceeding, have their bellies moitned & looened except the wind break forth downwards, or tore of urine do iue forth. And thee things happen in Feavers.

p.hi:
Namely in eential, not ymptomatical
Feavers, and uch as are dieaes of themelves.

div.head: APH. 74.
div.p: Thoe that have hope of Apothumations to come about the joynts, much urine thick and white doth deliver from the Apothume, uch as is wont to be avoided in painful Feavers the fourth day: when alo blood hall be voided out of the notrils, there hall be a diolution & deliverance peedily.

p.hi: For thoe urines purge out the humors which would caue the apothumations, and epecially if there be a bleeding at the notrils joyned, for then the caues iue out two ways.

div.head: APH. 75.
div.p: If any pis blood or filthy matter, it ignifies an exulceration of the Kidneys or bladder.

p.hi: That is, if he do it for a continuance, for otherwie it may proceed from ome other caue

div.head: APH. 76.
div.p: Thoe which have mall pieces of fleh, or as it were hairs iuing forth together with thick urine, do avoid thoe excrements from the Kidneys.

p.hi: Thoe mall pieces of fleh are part of the reins or kidneys, and are a manifet ign of their being ulcerated, but the hairs are onely bred there, but are no part of them.

div.head: APH. 77.
div.p: Thoe which avoid thick urine with certain things like bran, have their bladder infected with cabbednes.

p.hi: If the defect be not in the veins for uch tuff comes ometime from them.

div.head: APH. 78.
div.p: If any pis blood on a uddain, it is a ign there is ome vein of the Kidneys broken.

p.hi:
Namely meer and pure blood, and
without any external caue.

div.head: APH. 79.
div.p: They in whoe urine appeareth an hypotais or ediment full of and, have their bladder troubled with the tone.

p.hi: This Aphorim is mutilated and defective, for the and may come as well from the kidneys as from the bladder.

div.head: APH. 80.
div.p: If any one pis blood or clots of blood, and make his water by drops having pain in that part of the belly (which is between the Navel and the ecret parts) named hypogatrion: or at the eame line of the skin of the Cods, called perinaeum, and at the place called pecten (where the hair about the privy members groweth) then the places about the bladder are dieaed.

p.hi:
Namely all the parts belonging
to the bladder, and not the bladder onely.

div.head: APH. 81.
div.p: If any one pis blood or filthy matter, or little cales, and there be alo a tinking or trong mell, it betokens an exulceration of the bladder.

p.hi: The two firt accidents may happen upon the exulceration of any of the intruments erving to make water, but the cales and tink are proper igns of the bladder being ill-affected.

div.head: APH. 82.
div.p: Thoe which have an Apothume bred in the urinary paage, are delivered from it, the ame being brought to uppuration and broken.

p.hi: Which uppuration and breaking, gives the urine free paage.

div.head: APH. 83.
div.p:
Voiding of much urine in the
night doth ignifie mall evacuation of excrements by the Fundament.

p.hi: He makes particular mention of the night, becaue at that time by reaon of the leep Nature is mot buie about her concoction and ditribution.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This fift Book or Section is variable, yet it doth almot wholly intreat of the dieaes of women, and of the good and bad dipoitions of the womb.

div.head: APHORISM. 1.
div.p: A Convulion after taking Hellebore is deadly.

p.hi:
Namely after white Hellebore, and that for five caues. Firt by reaon of the agreement which is • etween the nerves and the mouth of the Stomack. Secondly by reaon of the biting humors which it draws to the mouth of the tomack. Thirdly by reaon of the abundant
evacuation the Hellebore caueth. Fourthly, by reaon of the attractive faculty by which it draws the moitnes from the nerves. And fiftly becaue it vehemently dryes up the ubtance of the nerves.

div.head: APH. 2.
div.p: A Convulion caued by a wound is deadly.

p.hi: Not always but for the mot part.

div.head: APH. 3.
div.p: The Hicket, or a Convulion after a copious flux of blood is evil.

p.hi: Becaue of the great emptines caued by the copious flux of blood, and becaue the Hicket is caued by a depraved motion of the ventricle.

div.head: APH. 4.
div.p: After an immoderate purgation, a Convulion or Hicket is evil.
For the ame reaon that they are evil after taking of Hellebore. Aph. 1.

div.head: APH. 5.
div.p: If one that is drunk uddainly fall dumb, he hall die with a Convulion unles he be taken with a Feaver, or preently recover his peech as oon as his urfet is diolved
Obj. How can wine being hot caue a Convulion which is a cold dieae?
A. Wine is hot moderately taken, over abundantly cold as a little oil powred upon a fire will increae it, but an over abonnding quantity thrown upon a little will put it out.

div.head: APH. 6.
div.p: Thoe who are taken with a Cramp or ditention called Tetanus, die within four days, or if they overpas them they recover.

p.hi: Becaue it is a ign that nature hath overcome the dieae.

div.head: APH. 7.
div.p:
The falling icknes, which is before ripenes of years may be cured:
but that which comes after five and twenty yeers of age for the mot part accompanies us to death.

p.hi: By ripenes of yeers he means 25 yeers of age, yet they are not all curable before that age, unles they take a care in dieting themelves.

div.head: APH. 8.
div.p: Thoe which have a pluriie, unles they be purged upwards within fourteen days, hall have their dieae turned into an impothume

p.hi: Namely pitting and purging uch matter upward.

div.head: APH. 9.
div.p: A Conumption likely happeneth in that age which is from the 18 to the 35.

p.hi: Namely that Conumption which comes by an exulceration of the Lungs.

div.head: APH. 10.
div.p:
Thoe who have the evil caue of the Squinancy and ecape it, that
evil paeth to the Lungs, and they dye within even days, but if they ecape, the humor impothumates.

p.hi: And if that impothumated humor be not purged out it breeds a Conumption.

div.head: APH. 11.
div.p: If the pittle which they void by coughing that are affected with a Conumption, do tink vehemently being cat upon the coals, and the hairs of the head do fall off, it is a deadly ign.

p.hi: For the more faculties are weakned in o much the worer cae the Patient is.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p: If a flux of the belly happen to them, which have their hair falling away by a Conumption; death is neer at hand.

p.hi:
Becaue it proceeding from weaknes alo, it hews a further weakening
of the natural faculties.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: Thoe which cough forth frothy blood, do retch and draw the ame out of the Lungs.

p.hi: And it is part of the very ubtance and fleh of the Lungs.

div.head: APH. 14.
div.p: If a flux of the belly happen to him which is in a Conumption it is deadly.

p.hi: This affirms what was aid before Aph. 12 and moreover that a flux of the belly added to a Conumption, is alone ufficient to kill without falling away of the hair.

div.head: APH. 15.
div.p: Thoe which are infected with an impothume by a Pluriie, if they be purged from the corrupt matter within forty days after the breaking of the impothume are cured, or otherwie they pas into a Conumption.

p.hi: For the matter will otherwie be o putrified that it will perih the lungs

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: Hot water too often ued, bringeth thee dicommodities: tendernes of the fleh, ditemperature of the inews, heavines, and tupefaction of the mind, fluxes of blood, faintings and wounings; and to thee things ucceeds death

p.hi: Hippocrates here wiheth us to hun; the exceive ue of any thing, though never o temperate.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: The ue of cold water, bringeth Convulions, ditentions or Cramps, blacknes, and cold Aguih hakings.

p.hi: This is alo not of the ue imply but of the immoderate ue of cold water.

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p:
Cold water is hurtful to the bones, teeth, inews, brain, and
marrow of the back. But that which is hot is good and profitable.

p.hi: All the parts here reheared are by nature the coldet.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p: We mut heat thoe things which are over cold, except thoe which pour forth or are inclined to pour forth blood abundantly.

p.hi: For when there are more dieaes then one coupled together, we mut make hat to cure that firt which is mot urgent.

div.head: APH. 20.
