div.p: Cold water biteth and nippeth Ulcers, hardeneth the skin, hindereth a orenes from maturation of the corrupt matter, caueth blacknes, bringeth forth cold hivering fits of Agues, Convulions, and ditentions of the inews.

p.hi: This Aphorim relates ome other hurts which cold water doth.

div.head: APH. 21.
div.p: Notwithtanding there is ome time when in the Cramp without an ulcer in a wel fleht young man in the midt of Summer, plentiful pouring out of cold water, doth call back the heat, and o the heat diolves the Cramp.

p.hi: This is not done by any vertue of its, but accidentally by drawing the natural heat outward in uch well fleht young men.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p:
Hot water yieldeth unto us a great token of ecurity and afety, when it caueth uppuration, yet not in all Ulcers. It oftneth and mollifieth the skin, and maketh it thin, it doth appeae pain, it mitigateth and aawageth cold hakeings, Convulions and ditentions: It diolveth the heavines of the head: It profiteth broken bones very much; epecially if they be
bare without fleh, and principally in the head, if they be ulcerated: it profiteth thoe things which are mortified, and ulcerated through cold, eating Ulcers in the Fundament, privy members, womb, and bladder. To all thoe hot water is a friend, and of good judgement; but cold water is an enemy and detroyer.

p.hi: Not in all ulcers, becaue ome wil not be brought to upuration by heat

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p:
We mut ue cold water to thoe ores from whence blood doth iue, or is about to iue, yet not to the ame place, but neer to it. And if any inflammation or burning of the parts, do incline to a red and bloody color, with freh cleer blood, apply cold water to them, but if the inflamations be inveterate and old it maketh them black. It helpeth the inflammation called
Eryipelas, if it be not ulcerated, for if it be it hurteth it.

p.hi: Now he relates what things cold water is good for.

div.head: APH. 24.
div.p: Cold things, as Snow and Ice are hurtful to the breat, they procure coughs, they caue ruptures of the veyns, and produce Rheumes.

p.hi: He hath poken of the effects of cold water, now he peaks of the hurt which other cold things do.

div.head: APH. 25.
div.p: Cold water poured out abundantly, doth eae and diminih the tumors and pains of the joynts, which are without ulceration. And alo gouty wellings and pains, and Convulions for the mot part, and diolveth the dolor, and diminiheth it. for a mall benumming hath the force of diolving and putting away of pan.

p.hi:
The end of this, phorim is a reaon
of the whole Aphorims aertion. As if he hould ay a little benumming puts away pain; cold water benumeth, therefore, &c

div.head: APH. 26.
div.p: Water that is quickly made hot, and quickly cools, is mot light.

p.hi: He means not by weight, but he peaks of that water which doth not long burthen the belly, and quickly paeth through.

div.head: APH. 27
div.p: It is good for them who deire to drink in the night, to fall aleep when they are very thirty.

p.hi: Becaue leep concocts the food, which being concocted ingenders blood, which nourihes and moitens the parts of the body.

div.head: APH. 28.
div.p: A Fumigation of odoriferous pices brings forth womens terms: and would be alo profitable for many other things, if it did not breed heavines of the head.

p.hi: For it doth excite the expulive faculty of the womb, and open the obtructions of the veines which touch the womb.

div.head: APH. 29.
div.p: Thou halt pruge a woman with child if neceity require, the 4th. month after conception, until the 7th month, though thoe that come neer the 7th, not o much: but the conception being younger or elder thou halt abtain.

p.hi: This Aphorim is the ame with the firt of the fourth Section.

div.head: APH. 30.
div.p: A woman with child, a vein being opened aborteth, and o much the rather if the conception be of any bignes.

p.hi: Becaue it taketh away part of its food, namely the conceptions.

div.head: APH. 31.
div.p: It is pernicious and deadly if a woman great with child be taken with any harp dieae.

p.hi: For large feeding will kill the mother by increaing the dieae, and little tore of food will tarve the conception.

div.head: APH. 32.
div.p: A woman is cured from vomiting blood, by her monethly terms iuing forth.

p.hi: By the Phyicians drawing down the blood to the lower parts.

div.head: APH. 33.
div.p: A flux of blood at the noe is good for a woman whoe monthly terms do fail contrary to the coure of nature.

p.hi: For if this happen not contrary to the coure of nature, uch a failing is nothing.

div.head: APH. 34.
div.p: If the belly be very laxative and looe to a woman with child, there is danger fo abortment.

p.hi:
Becaue the food is not ditributed to the liver and other parts of the
body, o that the food is taken away from the conception as when he is let blood.

div.head: APH. 35.
div.p: Sneeing happening to a woman grieved with uffocations of the womb, or that hath a difficult deliverance, is good.

p.hi: For by a vehement haking of nature, it excites it, redintegrates the natural heat which was almot extinguihed, and hakes off uch noxious humors as hanged upon ome part of the body.

div.head: APH. 36.
div.p: The monethly coures being dicoloured, and not coming forth always in the ame manner and time, declare a purgation to be neceary for the woman.

p.hi: To purge thoe humors which caue the dicoloration, and the alteration of time.

div.head: APH 37.
div.p: If the paps be uddenly extenuated and become lank, to a woman with child abortment doth follow

p.hi: This alo happeneth, for want of food for the conceived child.

div.head: APH. 38.
div.p: If one of the dugs be extenuated and become lank to a woman conceived with child with twins, he bringeth forth one of them before the due time; and if the right dug become lender, he bringeth forth the male, if the left, the female.

p.hi: For likewie the male conceptions lye on the right ide, the female on the left: as is et down Aph. 48.

div.head: APH 39.
div.p: If any woman, neither with child nor having been delivered of child have milk in her breats, her monethly coures have failed her.

p.hi: The blood which hould have turned to monethly terms, turning to milk in the breats.

div.head: APH. 40.
div.p: Women in whoe dugs there is blood heaped together, wil be mad

p.hi: For that blood is very bilious, which triking up into the head, caueth madnes.

div.head: APH. 41.
div.p: If you will know whether a woman have conceived or no, give her a potion of hony and water mixed together going to leep, and if he feel gripings and wringings of the belly, he hath conceived, if he do not, he hath not conceived

p.hi: For uch a potion is very windy, and the woman having conceived her womb doth pres down, and keep together the intrails.

div.head: APH. 42
div.p: If a woman conceived with child, bear a male he is freh and well-coloured, if he bare a female he is ill-colored.

p.hi:
This Aphorim is one of thoe
which for the mot part are true, though not always.

div.head: APH. 43.
div.p: If the inflammation called Eryipelas be bred in the womb, if the woman be with child, it proves deadly.
One reaon is becaue the chief cure for an Eryipelas is letting of blood and that mut not be done to a woman with child for fear of an abortment, Aph. 30.

div.head: APH. 44.
div.p: Thoe women which are very lean contrary to nature, and do bear children, do uffer untimely deliverance until they grow fatter

p.hi: Becaue that food which hould be for the child in the womb, goes to the nourihing of the mother.

div.head: APH. 45.
div.p:
Thoe women which being reaonable fat, and make abortion the econd or third month without
any manifet caue, have the ends of thoe veels which come to the womb called acetabula or Cotylidons full of a pituitous or phlegmy humor, neither can they contain the conception coming to any weight, but they being broken it falleth down.

p.hi: Wherby he mut of neceity abort

div.head: APH. 46.
div.p: Thoe which are fatter then nature requires and cannot conceive have the orifice of the womb compreed and cloed together by the fat Call of the guts, and cannot until they grow leaner.

p.hi: He means the inward orifice of the womb for it hath two.

div.head: APH. 47.
div.p: If the womb hall Apothumate in that part where it lieth neer the hip or huckle-bone, it mut be cured with tents dipped in a liquid medicine called in Greek Emmoton.

p.hi: It mut be thus cured the ore being firt broken either by art or nature.

div.head: APH. 48.
div.p: Men children for the mot part lye on the right ide of the womb and females on the left ide.

p.hi: This is becaue the womb is warmer on the right ide, by reaon of its vicinity to the Liver.

div.head: APH. 49.
div.p: A medicine procuring neezing put into the notrils doth drive and force out the Secundine, o that you top the notrils and mouth, cloe with the hand.

p.hi: Which if it remained would putrifie there, and with the tench offend the head.

div.head: APH. 50.
div.p: If a woman will tay her coures apply a very great cupping-glas under her breats.

p.hi: For there be veins which come up thither from the inferior parts.

div.head: APH. 51.
div.p: Thoe women which are conceived with child, have the orifice of the womb hut and cloed up.

p.hi: That the air may not get in and corrupt the eed, and that the heat of the womb may not get out.

div.head: APH. 52.
div.p: If milk flow plentifully out of the dugs of a woman bearing a child in her womb it ignifieth that the child is weak: but if the paps be hard and tiff, they declare a tronger conception.

p.hi: Becaue it hews in the former part that the child is not able to draw it for his own nutriment. But when they are olid it hews it hath nutriment enough, and that which uperabounds goes to the breats, and is there turned into milk.

div.head: APH 53.
div.p:
The dugs and paps become lender and lank to thoe women
which hall abort: but contrarily if they become hard, pain hall molet the paps, hips, eys, or knees, but they hall not uffer abortment.

p.hi: Becaue of the uperfluous matter which is brought thither from the womb.

div.head: APH. 54.
div.p: Thoe women which have the mouth of the womb hard, mut of neceity have it hut up.

p.hi: This Aphorim had been better placed immmediately after the Aphorim 51.

div.head: APH. 55.
div.p: Child-bearing women which are taken with Feavers, or are brought to a low tate without any manifet caue, do bring forth their birth painfully, and with danger: or are in danger of life by an untimely deliverance.

p.hi: Becaue it hews a great weaknes or imbecility in them.

div.head: APH 56.
div.p: If a Convulion, or wouning happen to a woman, in her flux of monethly terms, it is an evil thing

p.hi: If they be vehement or lat long, it may be deadly becaue the womb is exhauted and draws all the noble parts into a impathy with it.

div.head: APH. 57.
div.p: Womens terms flowing immoderately, dieaes are ingendred; and being uppret or topt, dieaes happen from the womb.

p.hi: By their immoderate evacuation, the whole body is cooled, and its forces weakened, if they be topt, in progres of time, excremental humors gather together in the womb.

div.head: APH. 58.
div.p:
The trangurie or dropping out of the urine doth happen by the inflammation of the traight gut,
and likewie of the womb, or if the reins be ulcerated. But if the liver be inflamed, the Hicket ucceeds.

p.hi: By reaon of the vicinity of the bladder to the traigbt gut and the womb, and becaue of the purulent matter of the reins paing through the bladder: and the hicket is caued by a high inflammation of the liver becaue it wells the liver, and opprees the ventricle, and the bilious humor falling from the liver comes into the ventricle.

div.head: APH. 59.
div.p: If a woman do not conceive, and thou wouldet know if he hall conceive at all, let her be wrapped round about with clothes, & make a fume under the lower parts, and if the cent be perceived to pas through her body to her notrils, and her mouth, know that he is not barren by any default in her elf.

p.hi: Becaue then the body is cleer of all vitious humors, and the womb it elf is in a good temper.

div.head: APH. 60.
div.p: If the monethly purgations keep their coure in a woman that is with child, it is impoible that the conception hould be well.

p.hi: Becaue it wants its aliment and food, being fed by that mentruous blood al the while it is in the womb.

div.head: APH. 61.
div.p: If a womans monthly coures top, and he have neither hivering cold nor Ague coming upon her, and he loath her meat, make account that he is conceived.

p.hi: For at the firt conceiving of a woman, the child cannot make ue of thoe coures for its food.

div.head: APH. 62.
div.p:
Thoe women which have their womb cold and dry do not conceive, nor thoe which have it over
moit, for the eed is extinguiht and periht in them. Alo thoe women cannot conceive which have thoe places over dry and hot, for the eed corrupts for want of nourihment. But thoe women which have obtained a moderate temperature of the places in repect of both the oppoitions and contrarieties they are fruitful.

p.hi: This Aphorim by right hould be placed next to the 59 Aph.

div.head: APH. 63.
div.p:
The ame conideration and reaon is likewie to be repected in men men, for either through the pongy ubtance of the body, the pirits are diipated and cattered abroad o that the eed cannot be cat forth; or ele the humor doth not iue forth becaue of its grones or thicknes; or ele becaue of coldnes it doth not grow hot,
to be collected in its proper place or by the means of heat, the very elf ame thing may happen.
This Aphorim is held to be purious, and none of Hippocrates, both by Galen and others.

div.head: APH. 64.
div.p:
It is not good to give milk to thoe who are troubled with the head-ach, or with Agues, nor to thoe who are troubled with flatus Hypocondriacus, nor to thoe who are troubled with thirt. It is alo naught for them which avoid cholerick excrements downwards, or to thoe which have harp Feavers, or have had ome copious evacuation of blood. But it is good for thoe which are in a Conumption, o they be not troubled with any vehement Feaver. It is alo good for long lingering and mild Agues, o there be none of the ore poken of ignes. And
thoe who are brought low without any apperant reaon or occaion,
The particular reaons for thee particular aertions may be een at large in Galen, Fuchius, and Heurnius Comments, which would be too long to rehere here.

div.head: APH. 65
div.p: They are eldom troubled with Convulions or madnes, which have apparent tumors with their ulcers. But Convulions and ditentions happen to them to whom the tumors hall uddenly vanih away, if they happen on the hinder part of the body. But if they happen on the fore part, there happeneth madnes, vehement pain of the ide uppuration or pitting of matter, and the bloody-flux.

p.hi:
Becaue the humors reide there. And if they go away by degrees alo
there is no danger for it hews, that the noxious humors are haken off and diolved.

div.head: APH. 66.
div.p: If no tumor nor welling appear in great and bad wounds, it is a great evil

p.hi: Becaue it ignifies a paing of the noxious humors to the principal parts.

div.head: APH. 67.
div.p: Soft tumors are good, raw and indigeted ones evil.

p.hi: Becaue the firt ignifie there is a concoction, and in the econd there is none.

div.head: APH. 68.
div.p: To one who hath a pain in the hinder part of his head, the vena recta in the fore-head being opened doth good.

The vena recta is that which is over againt that which is oppoite to that vein which nouriheth
the part which is evil affected, o the opening of it doth both evacuate and divert the noxious humors.

div.head: APH. 69.
div.p: Cold hakings and hiverings for the mot part do begin to women from the loyns, and through the back come to the head. But to men they do rather begin in the back part then in the forepart, as from the hinder part of the thighes and from the elbows; the rarity and thinnes of the skin is a token thereof, which thing, the hair there growing, doth declare and manifet.

p.hi: For the thicker the skin is, the l • s will hair grow upon it.

div.head: APH. 70.
div.p: Thoe which are taken with a Quartan Ague are not at all taken with Convulions: but if before they have been taken, upon the coming of the quartan, they are delivered.

p.hi: He means here uch Convulions as come by repletion of the nervous parts, with thin and pituitous humors, which by a quartan are both expelled and concocted

div.head: APH. 71.
div.p: Thoe who have their skin acide, and dry, die without weating, but thoe who have a looe and open skin, end their life with weat.

p.hi: He peaks here of thoe who have a Feaver.

div.head: APH. 72.
div.p: Thoe that are dieaed with the Jaundies are not much moleted, with windines.

p.hi: By reaon of the heat and trength of the parts belonging to the tomack, which caueth them to concoct the food fully and perfectly.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This Section doth almot altogether concern that part of the Art which foretelleth good and evil things to happen in dieaes.

div.head: APHORISM. 1.
div.p: IN a long lubricity and lipperines of the guts, if a owerih belching do happen, which was not before, it is a good ign.

p.hi: For it ignifies, that now the food remains a while in the tomack, till uch time at leat as it begins to concoct.

div.head: APH. 2.
div.p:
Thoe which have ther notrils more moit then others by nature,
and their eed alo do enjoy their health but badly; but thoe which have the contrary properties, are more healthful.

p.hi: By the notrils he means the brains which purge that way, and by the humidity of the Seed, the humidity of the whole body, the eed coming from the blood.

div.head: APH. 3.
div.p: In long fluxes of the bowels, loathing of meat is evil, and with a Feaver it is worer.

p.hi: Becaue it ignifies a mortification of the nourihing faculty.

div.head: APH. 4.
div.p: Ulcers which are every way mooth and bald.

p.hi: Becaue of an evil humor lying in the bottom, which eats up the roots of the hair, as alt earth doth the herbs roots which grow on it.

div.head: APH. 5.
div.p:
In the pains of the ides, breat,
and other parts, we mut conider whether they increae or differ much, or keep at a tay.

p.hi: Whither they differ namely in their kind, or in their vehemency, whether they be pricking tretching, or provoking.

div.head: APH. 6.
div.p: The dieaes and infirmities of the Kidneys and Bladder are of hard and difficult curation in old men.
• hich old age begins at fifty years which Hippocrates confirms in his ixt Book Epidemion where he aith he never aw or knew an ulcer of the reins or bladder cured after fifty years of age.

div.head: APH. 7.
div.p: Dolours and pains of the bely being aloft and in the upper part are more light & eaie, thoe which are not aloft are more vehement.

p.hi: We mut undertand this word aloft not according to the length and height of the body, but according to its depth and thicknes, o be thoe which are not aloft, he means thoe which are next to the back.

div.head: APH. 8.
div.p: Ulcers or ores in the body of thoe which are dieaed with the dropie, are not eaily cured.

p.hi: For an ulcer cannot be cured until it be exactly dryed, which cannot eaily be done in thoe who have the dropie, by reaon of their uperabundant humidity.

div.head: APH. 9.
div.p: Broad wheals are not very full of itching.

p.hi: For they are not bred by uch hot humors as thoe which are narrow and high.

div.head: APH. 10.
div.p:
Corrupt matter, water or blood
iuing out, by the notrils, mouth or ears, diolveth and cureth a vehement and grievous head-ach.

p.hi: If that the pain proceed from inflammation, or abundance of crude humors gathered in the head, for if it proceed from other caues, there mut be other cures.

div.head: APH. 11
div.p: The Haemorroides happening to thoe, which are troubled with melancholly and pain of the Kidneys are good.

p.hi: Both by reaon of the evacuation, and becaue they evacuate uch humors as ought to be evacuated.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p: Unles in the cures of Haemorroides which have long continued there be one vein kept open, it is to be feared that a Dropie or Convulion will hortly follow.

p.hi: That nature may by that means purge out thoe evil humors which remain.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: The Hick •• troubling us is put away by neezing.

p.hi: If the aid Hicket was caued by fulnes For by neezing not only the brain: but the tomack alo, by reaon of the nerves derived unto it, is vehemently haken, whereby the humors exciting the Hicket are evacuated.

div.head: APH 14.
div.p: If in him who hath a Dropie if the water flow from the veins into the belly, the dieae is diolved.

p.hi: If Nature or Phyick make evacuation of it from thence.

div.head: APH. 15.
div.p: Vomiting coming by the meer benefit of nature diolveth and riddeth away a long flux or loones of the belly.

p.hi: By reaon of the retraction and drawing back of the humors which <> downward.

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: A looenes of the belly, to one afflicted with a Pluriie or inflammation of the Lungs is an evil thing.

p.hi: Becaue it ignifies the liver to be o affected, by the conent of thoe parts which erve for repiration, that through weaknes it is not able to draw the aliment to it elf, and convert it into blood.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: It is good for him who hath a waterih dropping and running of the eys, if he be taken with a flux and loones of the belly.
Whereby Hippocrates hews us a convenient way how to cure uch eys, namely by drawing the humors which caue the dieae downwards

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p:
It is a deadly thing when the bladder is wounded, or the brain, or the heart, the midriff, any mall
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
gut, the Stomack or Liver.
The Greek word for wounded is here < in non-Latin alphabet > which ignifies deep wounded; for otherwie ome of thoe parts have been wounded and cured as Galen aith.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p: A bone perihed or cut off, a cartilage, gritle, or inew, or any little parcel of the eye-lid, or of the foreskin, being diminihed, do not grow or joyn together.

p.hi: Yet they may be knit together by ome other kind of ubtance as we ee in bones.

div.head: APH. 20.
div.p: If blood flow contrary to nature into any concavity it corrupteth and is putrified of neceity.

p.hi: That is, into any other concavity beides the veins and arteries.

div.head: APH. 21.
div.p:
If the wellings of veins in the legs, called varices; or the Haemorroides,
hall happen to them which are mad, their madnes is diolved.

p.hi: Becaue nature drives thoe humors which caue madnes into the more ignoble parts.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p: Breaches or fluxes of humors, which decend from the back to the elbow, are diolved by opening of a vein.

p.hi: By reaon that thoe humors are thereby evacuated.

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p: If fear and adnes continue long, it is a ign of melancholly.

p.hi: Namely without any outward caue, for thoe who are ad or fearful for any outward caue, their adnes and fear do not commonly lat long; but if they do, they will turn to melancholly, if not to madnes.

div.head: APH. 24
div.p: If any mall or lender gut be pierced, it doth not grow together again.
This was poken Aphorim 18. wherefore Galen and Heurnius would have it expunged.

div.head: APH. 25.
div.p: If the cholerick tumor Eryipulas being outward be returned inwards, it is evil; but if being inwards, it is turned outward, it is a good thing.
By this example Hippocrates hews that it is good to have all ores and dieaes of tbe body to come from the noble and inward parts to the ignoble and outward ones.

div.head: APH. 26.
div.p: Thoe burning feavers are diolved with dotage or raving, in which are trembling hakings.

p.hi:
They are indeed diolved, but that diolution at lat brings a general
diolution of the body by death

div.head: APH. 27
div.p: If the corruption, matter, or water do flow out altogether at once from them which are burnt or cauterized, or cut by the Chirurgion for the cure of the inward apothumation between the lungs and the breat, or of the Dropie, then the dieaed hall quetionles die
By thee examples Hippocrates hews that all total evacuations made at once, are noxious and deadly.

div.head: APH. 28.
div.p: Eunuchs or gelded men, are neither troubled with the Gout, nor with baldnes.

p.hi:
Becaue in Hippocrates time they ued a very good diet, and lived very temperately they were not troubled with the gout, though now adays they be, and their not being
bald comes from their native moiture, which makes them have a very thick skin.

div.head: APH. 29.
div.p: A woman is not troubled with the Gout unles her monthly terms fail her.

p.hi: The ame reaons may be alleadged for women as were et down in the former, for Eunuchs. But if her terms fail her, then the uperfluous humors being driven to the outward parts may caue it.

div.head: APH. 30.
div.p: A boy is not troubled with the Gout till he hath ued Venery.

p.hi: nles it come through their eed, or if the parents have had the French pox.

div.head: APH. 31.
div.p: Drinking of trong wine, a ba •• , a fomentation, phlebotomy, or a purgation doth cure the pain of the eyes.

p.hi: According as the caue of the dieae is, o mut the manner of the taking of it away be various.

div.head: APH. 32.
div.p: Thoe which tammer are for the mot part taken with a long flux of the belly.

p.hi: Becaue tammering hews an extraordinary humidity of the tongue, whereof the ventricle of neceity participates.

div.head: APH. 33.
div.p: Thoe which have our belchings are not much ubject to a Pluriie.

p.hi: Becaue our belching is a ign of much phlegm, and the Pluriie for the mot part invades thoe who are troubled with much choller.

div.head: APH. 34.
div.p: Great welling veins in the legs called varices, are not incident to them who loe their hair, and if they happen to have varices whoe hair do fall, their hair will grow again.

p.hi: Becaue thoe vicious humors which before corrupted the hair, are now gon down into the legs.

div.head: APH. 35.
div.p: If a cough come upon thoe which are troubled with a Dropie it is an evil thing.

p.hi: For it ignifies the watery humor to be o increaed, that it hath eied upon the rough artery, and o caueth danger of uffocation.

div.head: APH. 36.
div.p: Phlebotomy cureth the difficulty of making urine, but we mut open the inward veins.

p.hi: Namely that difficulty which proceeds from inflamation or fulnes

div.head: APH. 37.
div.p: If a tumor appear in the neck to him that is troubled with a Squinancy or Quinzy, it is good.

p.hi: Becaue the humors are come from the inward parts to the outward.

div.head: APH. 38.
div.p: Thoe who have hidden or deep Cancers are not to be cured of them; for they which are healed die oon, and thoe which are not healed, live longer.

p.hi: For fear of provoking or irritating them.

div.head: APH 39.
div.p: A Convulion is caued by repletion or evacuation. So is alo the Hicket.
Namely when the nerves are filled with ome thick or clammy humor, or over dryed. And the Hicket is aid by Galen to be as it were a Convulion of the tomack.

div.head: APH. 40.
div.p: They who have pain about the the hypocondrium without an inflammation are cured by a Feaver happening to them.

p.hi: Becaue the humors which caued it are diolved by the heat of the Feaver.

div.head: APH. 41.
div.p: If a uppuration or corrupt matter, hidden in the body doth not hew it elf, it is by reaon either of its own thicknes, or of that part of the bodies thicknes where it lies hidden.

p.hi: Yet we may find that there is uch corrupt matter hidden by two igns namely by the pain, and by a Feaver which it caueth.

div.head: APH. 42.
div.p: If the Liver wax hard to them which are affected with the yellow-Jaundies, it is an evil ign.

p.hi: For it ignifies there is either a hard tumor or an inflammation in the Liver

div.head: APH. 43.
div.p: The plenetick which are taken with a bloody-flux in the bowel, do dye of the Dropie, or a lipperines of the bowels, following a long flux.

p.hi: By plenetick he means thoe who have a tumor in the spleene, bred there, by a melancholly humor.

div.head: APH. 44.
div.p: They dye within even days, to whom the dieae called Ileos or pain in the mall guts hall happen after a Strangurie: unles a Feaver upervening, tore of urine iue forth.

p.hi: For the Fe ••• er with its heat concocts and ex •••• ates the thick humors, o that they may go out through the paage of the urine.

div.head: APH. 45.
div.p: If ulcers continue a yeer or longer, the bone of neceity mut grow foul, and the Cicatrices be hollow.

p.hi: Becaue the bone being perihed under, the fleh cannot grow up again as was aid Aph. 19. of this Section.

div.head: APH. 46.
div.p: Thoe which become Crookbackt by hortnes of wind, or a cough before they attain to ripenes of years, doe die quicklie.

p.hi: Becaue their bret or bulk doth not increae as their lungs and heart doth, they mut in a hort time to uffocated.

div.head: APH. 47.
div.p: Thoe are to be let blood or purged in the Spring time, to whom opening of a vein or purging may do good.

p.hi: For the Spring time being temperate is mot fit for purging or leting blood.

div.head: APH. 48.
div.p: The difficulty of the intetines & guts, coming upon them which are dieaed with the pleen is good.
Becaue the thick and melancholly humors are thereby eva • uated as Aph. 4 •

div.head: APH. 49.
div.p: Goutie dieaes, the inflammation being awaged, within fortie dayes deceae.

p.hi: For the inflammation wil be cured within forty dayes, if the Phyitian precribe right, and the patient be truly obedient.

div.head: APH. 50.
div.p: It mut needs be, that a Feaver, and Vomiting of choller mut come upon them, which have their brain wounded.

p.hi: A Feaver, becaue any principall members inflammation caueth a Feaver, and the vomiting of Choller becaue of the conent and agreement which is between the braine and the tomack, to which ome of the great nerves dicend from the braine.

div.head: APH. 51.
div.p:
Thoe which are in health being odainly taken with the head-ache,
and preently become dumb and nort, die within even days, unles a Feaver come upon them in the mean while.

p.hi: Becaue the Feaver heats, attenuates and reolves the windie pirit and the pituitous humors which caue thee ymptomes.

div.head: APH. 52.
div.p: We mut conider in their leeps if any part of the eyes appear; for if any of the white of them appears, the eye lidds not being fat cloed, if it doe not happen by a Flux of the bellie, or by the taking of ome medicinall potion, it is an evil and verie deadly igne.

p.hi: If it happen not through ome externall caue, for it ignifies an imbecillitie of the facultie which moves the eye lids.

div.head: APH. 53.
div.p:
That doting which is done with aughter is not o dangerous, as
that which is done with earnet adnee.

p.hi: For it does not proceed from o adut a Choler, as that which is done with earnet adnes.

div.head: APH. 54.
div.p: Painfull breathings in harp dieaes with a Feaver, as it were of uch as igh, and mourne, are evill.

p.hi: For it ignifies either a hardnes of the nerves or mucles, or a weakenes of naturall trength, or ome affect that caueth paine, or is convulory.

div.head: APH. 55.
div.p: Paine of the Gout doe mot commonly afflict, and are provoked in the Spring and Autumn.

p.hi:
In Spring becaue the humors gathered together in the winter are expelled from the tronger parts to the weaker; and in Autumn by reaon of its inequalitie, and becaue
the evill humors gathered together by eating of fruits in Summer ettle in thoe we aket parts.

div.head: APH. 56.
div.p: The falling down of humors are verie dangerous in melancholie dieaes at thoe eaons. And declare an Appoplexie, or a convulion, or maddnes or blindnes.

p.hi: If they fall down to the ventricles of the brain, they caue an Apoplexie if to the nerves a convulion, if to the ubtance of the braine madnes, if to the eyes blindnes.

div.head: APH 57,
div.p: Apoplexies are caued mot epeciallie from the fortieth to the ixtieth year.

p.hi: He means thoe Apoplexies which proceed from melancholie, which in thoe times abound in our bodies.

div.head: APH. 58
div.p: If the Call hang foorth of the bodie, it mut of neceity putrefie.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This eaventh Section is altogether prognoticall and foretelling things to come, and herein he intreateth of preages of health and death.

div.head: APHORISM. 1.
div.p: COldnes of the extreame parts in harp dieaes is evill.

p.hi: Becaue is hews there is a mightie • nflamation in ome of the inward parts, which like a cupping glae draws all the blood to it, and o leaves the extream parts cold.

div.head: APH. 2.
div.p: Fleh black and blew becaue of a foule dieaed bone, is an evill thing,

p.hi: For it hews there is a great putrefaction of the bone, and extinction of the natural heat.

div.head: APH, 3.
div.p: The hicket and rednes of the eyes after vomiting are evill

p.hi: For thee two together hew there is a great inflamation, either in the ventricle or the braine.

div.head: APH. 4
div.p: After weate, cold hiverings and hakings are not good.

p.hi: For it is a igne that nature is weake, and that the weat hath not had power to drive out all the noxious humors.

div.head: APH. 5.
div.p: After madnes, a bloodie Flux, the dropie, or an extanie or trane is good.

p.hi: For it ignifieth that the noxious humors are gone from the head to the lower parts

div.head: APH. 6.
div.p: Abhorring of meat in a long dieae, and the excrements avoided down without mixture of humors, are evill.

p.hi: Becaue, it hews the inbecilitie of the concocting facultie, and that all natural humidity is dried up by the eaverih heat.

div.head: APH. 7.
div.p: Cold hakings, and fond dotings, after much drinking of wine are evill

p.hi: The firt by reaon, it is a igne that the native heat is extinguiht by the much drinking of wine. And the doting proceeds from the heads being full of fervent blood and vapour.

div.head: APH. 8.
div.p:
After the breaking of an impothume
inwardly faintnee; vomiting and wouning.

p.hi: He peakes here of the breaking of impothumes which break in the tomack, for the ymptome of vomiting followes none ele.

div.head: APH. 9
div.p: After a Flux of blood, a Delirium or raveing, or a convulion are evill.

p.hi: For it hews a great drought of the bodie, and weaknes of the brains forces.

div.head: APH. 10
div.p: After the Iliack paion, or colick the hicket, raveing, or convulion are evil.

p.hi: Which are caued by the foulnes of the tomack and conent which is between the braine and the tomack.

div.head: APH. 11.
div.p: After a pleuriie, an Inflamation of the lungs is evill.

p.hi: Becaue it ignifies that part of the noxious humors is gone from the Ies noble part of the ribbs, to the more noble viz. the lungs.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p: A phrenie after an inflamation of the lungs is evill.

p.hi: The inflamation of the lungs, ending up vapours into the head, and they poeing the braine caue a Phrenie.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: A Convulion, or the Cramp, after hot burnings, are evill,

p.hi: Becaue it ignifies a great drynes of the nerves or inewes.

div.head: APH. 14.
div.p: Atonihment and raving through ome blow of the head is an evill igne.

p.hi: Becaue it ignifies that the wound hath penetrated to the • raine

div.head: APH. 15.
div.p: The pitting out of corrupt matter, after the pitting of blood is evill.

p.hi: Becaue it ignifies that the lungs are exulcerated.

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: A conumption and a Flux of the haire or of the bellie, coming after the pitting of corrupt matter are evilignes, for when the pitting is topped, the dieaed doe die.

p.hi: The firt part of this Aphorime is averred, Aphorim. 11. and 12. of the 5 Section, to which we referr you. The reaon of the econd part is becaue if the pitting be topped, the lungs are o oppreed with the abundance of flegme lying on them, that the patient is uffocated and trangled, for want of breath.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: The hicket comming through an inflamation of the liver is evill.

p.hi: For it hews the greatnes of the inflamation, of which the tomack alo participates, and being bitten by tore of choller wiming in it, it caues the hicket,

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p: A convulion or raving caued through watching is an evill thing

p.hi: For watching doth extreamly evacuate and exiccate the body; which caueth both the raving and convulion.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p: After the laying bare of a bone, the inflamation and hot tumor Eriipelas is evill.

p.hi: For it heweth a confluction thither of hot blood and choler, which corrode, and conume the adjacent fleh.

div.head: APH. 20.
div.p: Putrefaction or impotumation after, from the inflamation Eriipelas is evill,

p.hi: For it hews the malignitie of the aid Eriipelas, which doth not only exulcerate the upper parts of the bodie, but feeds deeper in, and creeps on to the ound parts

div.head: APH. 21.
div.p: A Flux of blood, after a trong pule in vlcers is evill.

p.hi: Firt becaue it hews an extreame inflamation to be joyned to the ulcer; econdly becaue this eruption or Flux cannot be, unles the month of the artery be opened: which is very difficult to be topped.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p: After a long paine of the parts belonging to the bellie, an impothumation is evill.

p.hi: Which it mut needs come to at lat unles death of the patient prevent it

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p:
After avoiding of unmixed excrements
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
downwards, a bloodie Flux is evill

p.hi: For uch humors will erode and perih ome parts of the intetines.

div.head: APH. 24.
div.p: Raving or Delirium enues after the wound of a bone, if it penetrate into the hollow or void pace.

p.hi: He peaks here of the bones of the head onely, as appears by the 14. Aph.

div.head: APH. 25.
div.p: A convulion after the taking of a purging potion bringeth death.

p.hi: Becaue is ignifies an incurable drought.

div.head: APH. 26.
div.p: A great cold of the uttermot parts, through vehement paine of the parts belonging to the bellie is evill.

p.hi: The reaon whereof is et downe in the comment of the 1. Aphorim of this Sect.

div.head: APH. 27.
div.p: If the dieae called Tenemus hall happen to a woman with child, it is the caue of abortment.

p.hi: This Tenemus is a great provocation or deire to goe to toole, and when they come thither can doe nothing.

div.head: APH. 28.
div.p: If either a bone, cartilage or inew, hall be cut in the bodie, it doth neither increae nor grow together againe.

p.hi: This was poken afore in the 19. Aphorim Sect 6.

div.head: APH. 29.
div.p: If a trong Flux of the bellie hall come upon him that is dieaed, with a dropie called Leacophlegmatia, it diolveth and cureth the dieae.

p.hi: Becaue it evacuates the efficient caue of the dieae, which is abundance of white flegme, from whence alo comes the dieaes name.

div.head: APH. 30.
div.p: They have a falling down of flegmatick humors from the head, which doe a vid froathie excrements out of the bellie.

p.hi: For phlegmatick humors being windie, it is no marvell if they be froathie.

div.head: APH. 31.
div.p: Sediments in urines, made in the time of agues like unto coure wheat-meal doe ignifie that the icknes hall continue long.

p.hi: For it hews a kind of gros thick humor, which cannot be diolved or voided in a hort pace.

div.head: APH. 32.
div.p: Cholerick ediments in urins, which at the firt were thinn, doe ignifie a harp dieae.

p.hi: For choller always caueth harp dieaes. And urines are always faithfull meengers of the affections of the veines.

div.head: APH. 33.
div.p: Thoe which makes divere urines, have a vehement diturbance in their bodie.

p.hi: For when the urines are o, it hews a manifoldnes of humors to be viciouly dieaed

div.head: APH. 34.
div.p: The urins in which bubbles doe wim a loft, ignifie a dieae of the reins, and that the dieae will endure long.

p.hi: For thoe bubbles proceding from humiditie which is extended about by a flatuous pirit, doe caue a cold dieae which cold dieaes are long.

div.head: APH. 35.
div.p: Thoe to whom a fattnes wims upon their vrine together & on a odain, it is a igne the dieae is in the reins, and aharp one too.

p.hi:
For if the dieae were in the whole bodie, it would come forth by little and little, and it is a harp
one, for the head of it melts the fat of the reins.

div.head: APH. 36.
div.p: If alo paines be caued to thoe which are dieaed with the grief of the kidneys about the mucles of the back bone, and have the ignes aboveaid, if they be felt towards the outward parts, look and expect that the impothume hall be alo outwardly. But if the pains bend and decline rather to the inward parts, we mut then expect the impothume will be inwards

p.hi: Namely if the paine hath been long and great.

div.head: APH. 37.
div.p: Vomiting of blood is wholome to them which doe it without a Feaver: but if it be with a Feaver it is an evill thing, and the cure and remedie of the ame, is to be performed with things that have a cooling and binding • ualitie.

p.hi: All vomits of blood are bad, Sect. 4. Aphorime. 25, therefore this mut be here undertood comparatively, namely that it is more tolerable without, then with a Feaver.

div.head: APH. 38.
div.p: Ditillations upon the upper bellie come to uppuration and ripenes within twenty dayes.

p.hi: By the upper belly, he means the tomach, whoe heat caueth the uppuration to be made o oon.

div.head: APH 39
div.p: If any one pis blood, or clots of blood, and be dieaed with the Strangury, the pain falling into the Perinaeum, Hypogatrium, and Pectinem, the places and part about the bladder are dieaed.

Perinaeum is the part between the privie Members and the Fundament. Hypogatrium the bottome of the belly: And Pecten
that part under the bellie where the haire grows.

div.head: APH. 40
div.p: If a mans tongue odainly become feeble, or any part of the body benummed without feeling, it is a igne of melancholie.

p.hi: For they proceeded from a thick juice which is partly melancholie partlie phlegmatick.

div.head: APH. 41.
div.p: If the hicket happen to old men, purged above meaure it is not good.

p.hi: Becaue uch a hicket is bad in all, epeciallie in old men, becaue in them all dieaes are greater, and more to he doubted by reaon of the imbecilitie of that age.

div.head: APH. 42.
div.p: If the feaver be not caued by choller, much warm water poured upon the head doth diolve it.

p.hi: nder the name of choler • e doth here comprehend all other humors, as Phlegme, blood and black choler.

div.head: APH. 43.
div.p: A woman hath not the ue of both hands alike,

p.hi: By reaon of the imbecilitie of womans nature.

div.head: APH. 44.
div.p: If a cleare and white matter doe iue out from them which are affected with corrupt matter, when they uffer cauterizing or inciion, they doe ecape: but if bloodie, tinking, and filthy matter doe iue forth, they die.

p.hi: By being affected with corrupt matter he means all which have anie corrupt tumor, but epecially uch as have it gathered between the lungs and the bret,

div.head: APH. 45.
div.p:
If clear and white matter doe
iue from them whoe liver is corrupted, and is burnt, they recover health: for the corrupt matter is contained in the coat, but if that which cometh forth be like the lees of oyle they die.

p.hi: The reaon of the Aphorim is et down in it, when he aith, the matter is contained in the coat, for if it penetrate into the fleh or ubtance of the liver they dye.

div.head: APH. 46.
div.p: Cure and heale pains of the eyes, which proceed from drinking of trong wine and bathing in hot water, by opening of a veyne.

p.hi: This Aphorime is by Gallen and Heurnius held to be purious and not worthy of Hypocrates; alludes to the 31. Aphorim of the 6 Section, yet it much differs from it.

div.head: APH. 47.
div.p: If a cough come upon one dieaed with the dropie, he is irrecoverable

p.hi: This and the 35 Aphorime of the 6 Section are all one.

div.head: APH. 48
div.p: Drinking of neat trong wine, and the opening of a veine diolves the Strangurie and Dyurie, but the inward veins mut be opened.

p.hi: He peakes not of all Stranguries and Dyuries, but only of that Strangurie or dropping of urine, which is caued by coldnes, and of that Dyurie, or the urines painful comming out, which proceeds from a vicous and flatuous humor.

div.head: APH. 49.
div.p: A welling and rednes ariing on the bret of him who have a Squiancie is good, for the dieae inclineth outwards.

p.hi: This differs nothing from the 37 of the ixt Section, but only in the place of the rednees ariing, o that in both, Hippocrates cope is to hew that in this dieae it is good to have thè humors tend outward.

div.head: APH. 50.
div.p: They die within three dayes, whoe braine begins to corrupt, but if they overpae them, they hall recover their health.

p.hi: Becaue the brain is a principal and mot noble part: But if they cape three daies it may be hoped, the dieae may remitt and that the naturall forces will ouercome it.

div.head: APH. 51.
div.p: Sneezing is provoked out of the head, the brain being much heated, or the void pace of the head being much moitned: For the aire incloed within, doth breake forth; and it makes a noie becaue it paeth through a narrow place.

p.hi: He peaks in this Aphorime only of that neezing which is caued by the motion if nature deires to driue out flatuous pirit out of the head.

div.head: APH. 52.
div.p: Thoe who are grieved with vehement pain of the Liver, are delivered from it, if an Ague come upon them.

p.hi: Which vehement pain cometh by windines which the feaver diperes

div.head: APH. 53.
div.p: Thoe which have occaion to have blood taken from them, mut be let blood in the Spring.

p.hi: This is part of the Aph. 47. Sect. 6 look upon that's Comment.

div.head: APH. 54.
div.p: Thoe which have phlegm incloed between the ventricle and the middriff, which is painful to them, having no paage into either of the bellies, are delivered from the dieae, the phlegm being turned through the veins into the body.

p.hi:
Matter may come out of the veins into any place of the body, and being
extenuated return into them again.

div.head: APH. 55.
div.p: Thoe have their belly filled with water and die, whoe Liver repleniht with water, makes an eruption of it in the upper part of the belly where the Caul is.

p.hi: This Aphorim peaks what is for the mot part, for by the help of nature and medicaments uch may be cured.

div.head: APH. 56.
div.p: Wine being drunk with an equal proportion of water, puts away orrow, yawning, and cold haking

p.hi: For wine by its moderate heat expels mot of thoe matters which caue thee ymptomes and tempereth the ret.

div.head: APH. 57.
div.p: Thoe which have a little welling in the urinary paage, they are delivered from it, the ame being brought to uppuration and broken.

p.hi: This Aphorim is the ame as the 82 of the fourth Secton where it was explained.

div.head: APH. 58.
div.p: They mut of neceity become dumb preently, which have their brain vehemently haken & troubled by ome outward occaion.

p.hi: In the word dumbnes he here comprehends all other voluntary motions.

div.head: APH. 59.
div.p: Hunger and fating is to be indured by bodies coniting of moit fleh. For fating dryeth the body.

p.hi: He means o much fating as will erve to correct the humidity of the fleh.

div.head: APH. 60.
div.p: Where there is alteration in the whole body, and it becometh cold and hot again, or changeth from one colour to another, it igniies length of the dieae.

p.hi: This Aphorim is repeated from that which is Sect. 4. Aph. 40.

div.head: APH. 61.
div.p: Much weat hot and dry frequently iuing forth, declares abundance of moitnes, which in a trong body is to be vacuated upwards, in a weak one downwards.

This Aphorim is thought by Galen to be purious, and alo the three following, yet Heurnius aith no uch thing. But aith this Aphorim means that weat which proceeds from uperabundance of moiture, and not from plenty of food.

div.head: APH. 62.
div.p: If Agues become more fierce and vehement every third day without intermiion they are dangerous. But in what manner oever they hall ceae it ignifieth they are void of danger.

div.head: APH. 63.
div.p:
Thoe which are afflicted with
long Feavers have little wellings or aches in the joynts.

div.head: APH. 64.
div.p: Thoe which have long wellings or pains in the joynts after a Feaver, do ue too plentiful a diet.

p.hi: Thee three lat Aphorims are the ame with the 43, 44, and 45 of the fourth Section, where they have been already explained.

div.head: APH. 65.
div.p: If any give the meat to one ick of a Feaver, which he giveth to a healthful peron, he hall trengthen the healthful peron, and increae the malady of the ick.

p.hi: This Aphorim alo is fally imputed to Hippocrates.

div.head: APH. 66.
div.p:
We mut look upon thoe things which pas through the bladder, whether they be uch as iue forth in properous health. For thoe which are unlike them, are unhealthful
ignes, but thoe which are like them, are healthful ignes.
This Aphorim peaks that which Hippocrates in a manner peaks elewhere: yet becaue it hath neither the form nor phrae of Hippocrates, Galen rejects it.

div.head: APH. 67.
div.p: Alo when the ediments, if thou halt uffer them to ret, and halt not move them, do ink down into the bottom like havings of guts or uch like matter, if they be few, they ignifie the dieae is but little; but if they be many, that it is great Then it is neceary to evacuate the belly downwards; otherwie if thou halt give broth and nourihments, without purging the belly, the more thou givet, the more thou halt offend.
This Aphorim Galen holds to be foited in by ome ophiter and lover of obcurity and to be none of Hippocrates.

div.head: APH. 68.
div.p: Crude, raw and undigeted excrements voided downwards, do proceed from black choller. If they be many, they proceed from a more copious quantity, if they be few, from a leer.

p.hi: This Aphorim participates of the formers obcurity, and by ome is joyned to it and made the latter part of the other.

div.head: APH. 69.
div.p: Spittings, in Feavers not intermitting, ah-coloured bloodyih, cholerick, tinking, are all evil. But if they come forth conveniently and eaily they are good, whether they iue out by the belly or bladder. And if any thing tays unpurged which hould have come forth, it is evil.

p.hi: This Aphorim is in a manner the ame with the 47 of the fourth Section

div.head: APH. 70.
div.p: When any one goeth about to purge unclean bodies, he mut make them oluble and fluxible.

p.hi: This Aphorim hath alo been explained in the tenth Aph. of the econd Section.

div.head: APH. 71.
div.p: Sleep and watchfulnes, if they exceed a meaure, are a dieae.

p.hi: This is alo the ame Aphorim in ubtance with the third of the econd Section,

div.head: APH. 72.
div.p: In Feavers not intermitting, if the exterior parts be cold, and the inward burning and the patient have a Feaver.

p.hi: This Aphorim was better et down Sect. 4. Aph. 48. for why hould he add at the end of this, if the patient have a Feaver when he had already aid in the beginning, In Feavers not intermitting.

div.head: APH. 73.
div.p: In a Feaver not intermitting, if a lip, noe, eye, or eye-brow be perverted and turned awry, if the ick man do not ee nor hear, whatoever of thee things hall happen to a weak ick man, death is neer at hand.

p.hi: This Aphorim is the ame with the 49 of Sect. 4.

div.head: APH. 74.
div.p: After white phlegme comes a Dropie.

p.hi: Namely when the body and its veels, are abundantly filled with it

div.head: APH. 75.
div.p: From a looenes of the belly, proceeds a bloody-flux.

p.hi: Not from all loonees, but onely uch as are long lating, and bilious as Aph 23.

div.head: APH. 76.
div.p: After a bloody-flux comes a Lienteria.

p.hi: Which is a flux of undigeted meat. See Sect. 6. Aph. 43.

div.head: APH. 77.
div.p: After the corruption of the bone comes the impot humation of it called in Greek Sphacelimos.

p.hi: It may be alo taken for a Gangrening of the fleh about it.

div.head: APH 78.
div.p: After vomiting of blood, a Conumption, and an evacuation of filthy purulent matter doth enue.
This Aphorim is et down everal ways, but I have followed Galens expoition.

div.head: APH. 79.
div.p:
We ought to behold what things they be which pas out by urines or by the belly, and what things iue out through the fleh. And we mut alo conider and behold whether the body do decline in any other thing from nature. For if little be a voided the dieae is
little, if much, the dieae is great, and if very much it is deadly.

p.hi: To the end that the Phyician may know the dieae, he mut take pecial notice of the excrements, and examine them in ubtance, quantity, quality, and the time and manner of getting them out. For the excrements repreent the Idea of thoe parts from whence they proceed.
